   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading">Iran</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="vector-body"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" lang="en" dir="ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       "Persia" redirects here. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Iran_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Iran (disambiguation)">Iran (disambiguation)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persia_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Persia (disambiguation)">Persia (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Not to be confused with <a href="/wiki/Persis" title="Persis">Persis</a>.
      </div> 
      <p class="mw-empty-elt"> </p> 
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Country in Western Asia
      </div> 
      <p> <span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r994658806">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Iran&amp;params=32_N_53_E_dim:1000km_type:country_region:IR"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">32°N</span> <span class="longitude">53°E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">32°N 53°E</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">32; 53</span></span></span></a></span></span></span> </p>

            <li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 18% <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijani_language" title="Azerbaijani language">Azerbaijani</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Turkic_languages" title="Turkic languages">Turkic dialects</a> <span style="font-size:92%;line-height:1.30em;">(incl. <a href="/wiki/Qashqai_language" title="Qashqai language">Qashqai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkmen_language" title="Turkmen language">Turkmen</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-britannicalanguages_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannicalanguages-2">[2]</a></sup></span> </li>
            <li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 10% <a href="/wiki/Kurdish_languages" title="Kurdish languages">Kurdish</a> </li>
            <li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 7% <a href="/wiki/Gilaki_language" title="Gilaki language">Gilak</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mazanderani_language" title="Mazanderani language">Mazanderani</a> </li>

            <li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2% other<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-3">[3]</a></sup> <span style="font-size:92%;line-height:1.30em;">(incl. <a href="/wiki/Armenian_language" title="Armenian language">Armenian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_Neo-Aramaic" title="Assyrian Neo-Aramaic">Assyrian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georgian_language" title="Georgian language">Georgian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laki_language" title="Laki language">Laki</a>, <a href="/wiki/Semnani_languages" title="Semnani languages">Semnani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Talysh_language" title="Talysh language">Talysh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tati_language_(Iran)" title="Tati language (Iran)">Tati</a>)</span></li>
           </ul> 
          </div></td>
        </tr>

         <th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Ethnic_group" title="Ethnic group">Ethnic&nbsp;groups</a> 
          <div style="font-weight:normal;display:inline;"></div></th>
         <td class="infobox-data">
          <div class="mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" style="text-align: center; font-size: 95%;"> 
           <div style="line-height: 1.6em; font-weight: bold; font-size: 100%; text-align: left; background:transparent;text-align:left;font-weight:normal;font-size:100%;">
            <div>
             List of ethnicities
            </div>
           </div> 
           <ul class="mw-collapsible-content" style="font-size: 105%; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; line-height: inherit; text-align: left; list-style: none none; margin-left: 0;">
            <li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 61% <a href="/wiki/Persians" title="Persians">Persian</a> </li>
            <li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 16% <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijanis" title="Azerbaijanis">Azerbaijani</a> </li>
            <li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 10% <a href="/wiki/Kurds" title="Kurds">Kurd</a> </li>
            <li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 6% <a href="/wiki/Lurs" title="Lurs">Lur</a> <span style="font-size:92%;line-height:1.30em;">(incl. <a href="/wiki/Bakhtiari_people" title="Bakhtiari people">Bakhtiari</a>)</span> </li>
            <li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2% <a href="/wiki/Turkmens" title="Turkmens">Turkmen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ethnicities_in_Iran#Turkic_peoples" title="Ethnicities in Iran">other Turkic peoples</a> </li>
            <li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2% <a href="/wiki/Baloch_people" title="Baloch people">Baloch</a> </li>
            <li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2% <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Arabs" title="Iranian Arabs">Arab</a> </li>
            <li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 1% other<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-3">[3]</a></sup></li>
           </ul> 
          </div></td>
        </tr>

          <div class="plainlist">
           <ul>
            <li><a href="/wiki/.ir" title=".ir">.ir</a></li>
            <li><a href="/wiki/.ir" title=".ir">ایران.</a></li>
           </ul>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table role="presentation" class="metadata mbox-small noprint selfref" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;width: 290px;"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="mbox-image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Farsi.svg/40px-Farsi.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="29" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Farsi.svg/60px-Farsi.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Farsi.svg/80px-Farsi.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="324" data-file-height="236"></td> 
         <td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="vertical-align:middle; font-size:95%;">You may need <a href="/wiki/Help:Arabic" title="Help:Arabic">rendering support</a> to display the <a href="/wiki/Persian_alphabet" title="Persian alphabet">Persian text</a> in this article correctly.</td>
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><b>Iran</b> (<a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a>: <span lang="fa" dir="rtl">ایران</span>‎ <i lang="fa-Latn" title="Persian-language romanization">Irān</i> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Persian" title="Help:IPA/Persian">[ʔiːˈɾɒːn]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Iran-Pronunciation.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/17/Iran-Pronunciation.ogg" class="internal" title="Iran-Pronunciation.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), also called <b>Persia</b><sup id="cite_ref-Fishman_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fishman-11">[11]</a></sup> and officially the <b>Islamic Republic of Iran</b> (<a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a>: <span lang="fa" dir="rtl">جمهوری اسلامی ایران</span>‎ <i lang="fa-Latn" title="Persian-language romanization">Jomhuri-ye Eslāmi-ye Irān</i> <span style="font-size:85%;">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fa-ir-JEI_(1).ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4b/Fa-ir-JEI_%281%29.ogg" class="internal" title="Fa-ir-JEI (1).ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Persian" title="Help:IPA/Persian">[dʒomhuːˌɾije eslɒːˌmije ʔiːˈɾɒn]</a></span>), is a country in <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a>. It is bordered to the northwest by <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[a]</a></sup> to the north by the <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">Caspian Sea</a>, to the northeast by <a href="/wiki/Turkmenistan" title="Turkmenistan">Turkmenistan</a>, to the east by <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, to the southeast by <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, to the south by the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">Persian Gulf</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Oman" title="Gulf of Oman">Gulf of Oman</a>, and to the west by <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>. Iran covers an area of 1,648,195&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (636,372&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), with a population of 83 million. It is the second largest country in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>, and its capital and largest city is <a href="/wiki/Tehran" title="Tehran">Tehran</a>. </p>
      <p>Iran is home to one of the world's oldest civilizations,<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[13]</a></sup> beginning with the formation of the <a href="/wiki/Elam" title="Elam">Elamite</a> kingdoms in the fourth millennium BC. It was first unified by the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_peoples" title="Iranian peoples">Iranian</a> <a href="/wiki/Medes" title="Medes">Medes</a> in the seventh century BC,<sup id="cite_ref-Encyclopædia_Britannica_Encyclopedia_Article:_Media_ancient_region,_Iran_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclopædia_Britannica_Encyclopedia_Article:_Media_ancient_region,_Iran-15">[14]</a></sup> and reached its territorial height in the sixth century BC, when <a href="/wiki/Cyrus_the_Great" title="Cyrus the Great">Cyrus the Great</a> founded the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a>, which became <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_empires" title="List of largest empires">one of the largest empires in history</a> and the world's first superpower.<sup id="cite_ref-book_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-book-16">[15]</a></sup> The empire fell to <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a> in the fourth century BC and was divided into several <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_period" title="Hellenistic period">Hellenistic states</a>. An Iranian rebellion established the <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian Empire</a> in the third century BC, which was succeeded in the third century AD by the <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sasanian Empire</a>, a major world power for the next four centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-Norman_A._Stillman_p._22_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Norman_A._Stillman_p._22-17">[16]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Byzantine_Studies_2006,_p._29_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Byzantine_Studies_2006,_p._29-18">[17]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Persia" title="Muslim conquest of Persia">Arab Muslims conquered the empire</a> in the seventh century AD, which led to the <a href="/wiki/Islamization_of_Iran" title="Islamization of Iran">Islamization of Iran</a>, and it subsequently becoming a major center of <a href="/wiki/Islamic_culture" title="Islamic culture">Islamic culture</a> and learning, with its art, literature, philosophy, and architecture spreading across the Muslim world and beyond during the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age" title="Islamic Golden Age">Islamic Golden Age</a>. Over the next two centuries, a series of <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Intermezzo" title="Iranian Intermezzo">native Muslim dynasties</a> emerged before the <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_dynasty" title="Seljuk dynasty">Seljuq Turks</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ilkhanate" title="Ilkhanate">Mongols</a> conquered the region. In the 15th century, the native <a href="/wiki/Safavid_dynasty" title="Safavid dynasty">Safavids</a> re-established a unified Iranian state and national identity,<sup id="cite_ref-Sarkhosh_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sarkhosh-4">[4]</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/Safavid_conversion_of_Iran_to_Shia_Islam" title="Safavid conversion of Iran to Shia Islam">the country's conversion to Shia Islam</a> marking a turning point in Iranian and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Islam" title="History of Islam">Muslim history</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Andrew_J._Newman_2006_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Andrew_J._Newman_2006-5">[5]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-savoryeiref_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-savoryeiref-19">[18]</a></sup> Under the reign of <a href="/wiki/Nader_Shah" title="Nader Shah">Nader Shah</a> in the 18th century, Iran once again became a major world power,<sup id="cite_ref-books.google.nl_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.nl-20">[19]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (November 2020)">page&nbsp;needed</span></a></i>]</sup> though by the 19th century a series of <a href="/wiki/Russo-Persian_Wars" title="Russo-Persian Wars">conflicts</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a> led to significant territorial losses.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFisherAveryHamblyMelville1991329–330_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFisherAveryHamblyMelville1991329–330-21">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Timothy_C._Dowling_pp._728-730_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Timothy_C._Dowling_pp._728-730-22">[21]</a></sup> The early 20th century saw the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Constitutional_Revolution" title="Persian Constitutional Revolution">Persian Constitutional Revolution</a>. Efforts to nationalize its fossil fuel supply from Western companies led to an <a href="/wiki/1953_Iranian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1953 Iranian coup d'état">Anglo-American coup in 1953</a>, which resulted in greater <a href="/wiki/Autocracy" title="Autocracy">autocratic</a> rule under <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Reza_Pahlavi" title="Mohammad Reza Pahlavi">Mohammad Reza Pahlavi</a> and growing Western political influence.<sup id="cite_ref-Anthony_H._Cordesman_p_22_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Anthony_H._Cordesman_p_22-23">[22]</a></sup> He went on to launch <a href="/wiki/White_Revolution" title="White Revolution">a far-reaching series of reforms in 1963</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[23]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Revolution" title="Iranian Revolution">Iranian Revolution</a>, the current <a href="/wiki/Islamic_republic" title="Islamic republic">Islamic Republic</a> was established in 1979<sup id="cite_ref-britannica1_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica1-25">[24]</a></sup> by <a href="/wiki/Ruhollah_Khomeini" title="Ruhollah Khomeini">Ruhollah Khomeini</a> who became the country's first <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Leader_of_Iran" title="Supreme Leader of Iran">Supreme Leader</a>. </p>
      <p>The Government of Iran is an <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islamic</a> <a href="/wiki/Theocracy" title="Theocracy">theocracy</a> which includes elements of a <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">presidential democracy</a>, with the ultimate authority vested in an autocratic "Supreme Leader",<sup id="cite_ref-politicalsystem_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-politicalsystem-26">[25]</a></sup> a position held by <a href="/wiki/Ali_Khamenei" title="Ali Khamenei">Ali Khamenei</a> since 1989 following Khomeini's death. The Iranian government is widely considered to be <a href="/wiki/Authoritarianism" title="Authoritarianism">authoritarian</a>, and has attracted widespread criticism for its significant constraints and abuses against <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Human rights in the Islamic Republic of Iran">human rights</a> and civil liberties,<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[29]</a></sup> including several violent suppressions of mass protests, <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Iran" title="Elections in Iran">unfair elections</a>, and limited rights for <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_rights_in_Iran" title="Women's rights in Iran">women</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Rights_of_the_Child_in_Iran" title="The Rights of the Child in Iran">children</a>. </p>
      <p>Iran is a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional</a> and <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a>, with a geopolitically strategic location.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[30]</a></sup> Iran is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">UN</a>, <a href="/wiki/Economic_Cooperation_Organization" title="Economic Cooperation Organization">ECO</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">OIC</a>, and <a href="/wiki/OPEC" title="OPEC">OPEC</a>. It has large reserves of <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel" title="Fossil fuel">fossil fuels</a> — including the world's second largest <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_reserves_in_Iran" title="Natural gas reserves in Iran">natural gas supply</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_proven_oil_reserves" title="List of countries by proven oil reserves"> fourth largest</a> proven <a href="/wiki/Oil_reserves" title="Oil reserves">oil reserves</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[31]</a></sup> The country's rich cultural legacy is reflected in part by its 22 <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Iran" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Iran">UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a>, the third largest number in Asia and 10th largest in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[32]</a></sup> Historically a multi-ethnic country, Iran remains a pluralistic society comprising <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Iran" title="Demographics of Iran">numerous ethnic, linguistic, and religious groups</a>, the largest being <a href="/wiki/Persians" title="Persians">Persians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijanis" title="Azerbaijanis">Azeris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kurds" title="Kurds">Kurds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mazanderani_people" title="Mazanderani people">Mazandaranis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lurs" title="Lurs">Lurs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-3">[3]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">

          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-52"><a href="#Fashion_and_clothing"><span class="tocnumber">8.14</span> <span class="toctext">Fashion and clothing</span></a></li> 
         </ul> </li> 
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-53"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li> 
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-54"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">10</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li> 
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-55"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">11</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> 
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-56"><a href="#Bibliography"><span class="tocnumber">12</span> <span class="toctext">Bibliography</span></a></li> 
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-57"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">13</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li> 
       </ul> 
      </div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Name">Name</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Iran" title="Name of Iran">Name of Iran</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The term <i><a href="/wiki/Iran_(word)" title="Iran (word)">Iran</a></i> derives directly from <a href="/wiki/Middle_Persian" title="Middle Persian">Middle Persian</a> <i lang="pal-Latn" title="Middle Persian-language romanization">Ērān</i>, first attested in a third-century inscription at <a href="/wiki/Rustam_Relief" class="mw-redirect" title="Rustam Relief">Rustam Relief</a>, with the accompanying <a href="/wiki/Parthian_language" title="Parthian language">Parthian</a> inscription using the term <i lang="xpr-Latn" title="Parthian-language romanization">Aryān</i>, in reference to the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Iranian people">Iranians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MacKenzie_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacKenzie-34">[33]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Middle_Iranian" class="mw-redirect" title="Middle Iranian">Middle Iranian</a> <i>ērān</i> and <i>aryān</i> are oblique plural forms of <a href="/wiki/Gentilic" class="mw-redirect" title="Gentilic">gentilic</a> nouns <i>ēr-</i> (Middle Persian) and <i>ary-</i> (Parthian), both deriving from <a href="/wiki/Proto-Iranian" class="mw-redirect" title="Proto-Iranian">Proto-Iranian</a> <i>*arya-</i> (meaning "<a href="/wiki/Aryan" title="Aryan">Aryan</a>", i.e. "of the Iranians"),<sup id="cite_ref-MacKenzie_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacKenzie-34">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Schmitt_Aryans1_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schmitt_Aryans1-35">[34]</a></sup> recognized as a derivative of <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European" class="mw-redirect" title="Proto-Indo-European">Proto-Indo-European</a> <i><span title="Proto-Indo-European language" class="Unicode" lang="ine" style="white-space:nowrap;">*ar-yo-</span></i>, meaning "one who assembles (skilfully)".<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[35]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_languages" title="Iranian languages">Iranian languages</a>, the gentilic is attested as a self-identifier, included in ancient inscriptions and the literature of the <a href="/wiki/Avesta" title="Avesta">Avesta</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Bailey_Arya_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bailey_Arya-37">[36]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[b]</a></sup> and remains also in other Iranian ethnic names <i><a href="/wiki/Alans" title="Alans">Alan</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Ossetian_language" title="Ossetian language">Ossetian</a>: <span lang="os">Ир</span> <i lang="os-Latn" title="Ossetian-language romanization">Ir</i>) and <i><a href="/wiki/Iron_people" title="Iron people">Iron</a></i> (<span lang="os" title="Ossetian-language text">Ирон</span>).<sup id="cite_ref-Schmitt_Aryans1_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schmitt_Aryans1-35">[34]</a></sup> According to the Iranian mythology, the country's name comes from the name of <a href="/wiki/Iraj" title="Iraj">Iraj</a>, a legendary prince and shah who was killed by his brothers.<sup id="cite_ref-Iranica_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Iranica-39">[37]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Historically, Iran has been referred to as <i>Persia</i> by <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">the West</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Fishman_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fishman-11">[11]</a></sup> due mainly to the writings of <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greek</a> historians who referred to all of Iran as <i lang="grc-Latn" title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language romanization">Persís</i> (<a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Ancient Greek language">Ancient Greek</a>: <span lang="grc">Περσίς</span>; from <a href="/wiki/Old_Persian" title="Old Persian">Old Persian</a> <span lang="peo" title="Old Persian (ca. 600-400 B.C.)-language text">𐎱𐎠𐎼𐎿</span> <i lang="peo-Latn" title="Old Persian (ca. 600-400 B.C.)-language romanization">Pārsa</i>),<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[38]</a></sup> meaning "land of the <a href="/wiki/Persians" title="Persians">Persians</a>", while <a href="/wiki/Persis" title="Persis">Persis</a> itself was one of the provinces of ancient Iran that is today known as <a href="/wiki/Fars_Province" title="Fars Province">Fars</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Arnold_Wilson_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Arnold_Wilson-41">[39]</a></sup> As the most extensive interaction the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greeks" class="mw-redirect" title="Ancient Greeks">ancient Greeks</a> had with any outsider was with the Persians, the term persisted, even long after the <a href="/wiki/Greco-Persian_Wars" title="Greco-Persian Wars">Greco-Persian Wars</a> (499–449 BC). </p>
      <p>In 1935, <a href="/wiki/Reza_Shah" title="Reza Shah">Reza Shah</a> requested the international community to refer to the country by its native name, <i>Iran</i>, on <a href="/wiki/Nowruz" title="Nowruz">Nowruz</a>, falling on 21 March 1935; effective 22 March that year.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[40]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[41]</a></sup> Opposition to the name change led to the reversal of the decision in 1959, and Professor <a href="/wiki/Ehsan_Yarshater" title="Ehsan Yarshater">Ehsan Yarshater</a>, editor of <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Iranica" title="Encyclopædia Iranica">Encyclopædia Iranica</a></i>, propagated a move to use <i>Persia</i> and <i>Iran</i> interchangeably.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[42]</a></sup>Today, both <i>Iran</i> and <i>Persia</i> are used in cultural contexts, while <i>Iran</i> remains irreplaceable in official state contexts.<sup id="cite_ref-artarena_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-artarena-45">[43]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Historical and cultural usage of the word <i>Iran</i> is not restricted to the modern state proper.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[44]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[45]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[46]</a></sup> "<a href="/wiki/Greater_Iran" title="Greater Iran">Greater Iran</a>" (<i>Irānzamīn</i> or <i>Irān e Bozorg</i>)<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[47]</a></sup> refers to territories of the Iranian cultural and linguistic zones. In addition to modern Iran, it includes portions of the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[48]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (November 2020)">page&nbsp;needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pronunciation">Pronunciation</span></h3> 
      <p>The Persian pronunciation of <i>Iran</i> is <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Persian" title="Help:IPA/Persian">[ʔiːˈɾɒːn]</a></span>. Common <a href="/wiki/English_in_the_Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="English in the Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth English</a> pronunciations of <i>Iran</i> are listed in the <i><a href="/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary" title="Oxford English Dictionary">Oxford English Dictionary</a></i> as <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ɑː/: 'a' in 'father'">ɑː</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> and <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span>,<sup id="cite_ref-Oxford_Iran_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oxford_Iran-51">[49]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/American_English" title="American English">American English</a> dictionaries such as <a href="/wiki/Merriam-Webster" title="Merriam-Webster">Merriam-Webster</a>'s provide pronunciations which map to <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ɑː/: 'a' in 'father'">ɑː</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span>-<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/aɪ/: 'i' in 'tide'">aɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span>,<sup id="cite_ref-MW_Iran_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MW_Iran-52">[50]</a></sup> or likewise in <i><a href="/wiki/Random_House_Webster%27s_Unabridged_Dictionary" title="Random House Webster's Unabridged Dictionary">Random House Webster's Unabridged Dictionary</a></i> as <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ɑː/: 'a' in 'father'">ɑː</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/aɪ/: 'i' in 'tide'">aɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span>. The <i><a href="/wiki/Cambridge_Advanced_Learner%27s_Dictionary" title="Cambridge Advanced Learner's Dictionary">Cambridge Dictionary</a></i> lists <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ɑː/: 'a' in 'father'">ɑː</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> as the British pronunciation and <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> as the American pronunciation. Similarly, Glasgow-based <i><a href="/wiki/Collins_English_Dictionary" title="Collins English Dictionary">Collins English Dictionary</a></i> provides both <a href="/wiki/English_language_in_England" title="English language in England">English English</a> and American English pronunciations. The pronunciation guide from <a href="/wiki/Voice_of_America" title="Voice of America">Voice of America</a> also provides <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ɑː/: 'a' in 'father'">ɑː</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[51]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The American English pronunciation <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/aɪ/: 'i' in 'tide'">aɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling">eye-<span style="font-size:90%">RAN</span></i></a> may be heard in U.S. media. Max Fisher in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">The Washington Post</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[52]</a></sup> prescribed <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/iː/: 'ee' in 'fleece'">iː</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ɑː/: 'a' in 'father'">ɑː</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> for <i>Iran</i>, while proscribing <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/aɪ/: 'i' in 'tide'">aɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_American_Heritage_Dictionary_of_the_English_Language" title="The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language">The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language</a></i>, in the dictionary's 2014 Usage Ballot, addressed the topic of the pronunciations of Iran and Iraq.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[53]</a></sup> According to this survey, the pronunciations <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ɑː/: 'a' in 'father'">ɑː</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> and <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> were deemed almost equally acceptable, while <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ɑː/: 'a' in 'father'">ɑː</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> was preferred by most panelists participating in the ballot. With regard to the <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/aɪ/: 'i' in 'tide'">aɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> pronunciation, more than 70% of the panelists deemed it unacceptable. Among the reasons given by those panelists were that <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/aɪ/: 'i' in 'tide'">aɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> has "hawkish connotations" and sounds "angrier", "xenophobic", "ignorant", and "not<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>... cosmopolitan". The <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/aɪ/: 'i' in 'tide'">aɪ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> pronunciation remains standard and acceptable, reflected in the entry for <i>Iran</i> in the American Heritage Dictionary itself, as well as in each of the other major dictionaries of American English. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Iran" title="History of Iran">History of Iran</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Iranian_history" title="Timeline of Iranian history">Timeline of Iranian history</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Iran" title="Prehistory of Iran">Prehistory of Iran</a> and <a href="/wiki/Archaeological_sites_in_Iran" class="mw-redirect" title="Archaeological sites in Iran">Archaeological sites in Iran</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Cave_painting_in_Doushe_cave,_Lorstan,_Iran,_8th_millennium_BC.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Cave_painting_in_Doushe_cave%2C_Lorstan%2C_Iran%2C_8th_millennium_BC.JPG/220px-Cave_painting_in_Doushe_cave%2C_Lorstan%2C_Iran%2C_8th_millennium_BC.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="149" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Cave_painting_in_Doushe_cave%2C_Lorstan%2C_Iran%2C_8th_millennium_BC.JPG/330px-Cave_painting_in_Doushe_cave%2C_Lorstan%2C_Iran%2C_8th_millennium_BC.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Cave_painting_in_Doushe_cave%2C_Lorstan%2C_Iran%2C_8th_millennium_BC.JPG/440px-Cave_painting_in_Doushe_cave%2C_Lorstan%2C_Iran%2C_8th_millennium_BC.JPG 2x" data-file-width="486" data-file-height="330"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Cave_painting_in_Doushe_cave,_Lorstan,_Iran,_8th_millennium_BC.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A <a href="/wiki/Cave_painting" title="Cave painting">cave painting</a> in Doushe cave, <a href="/wiki/Lorestan_Province" title="Lorestan Province">Lorestan</a>, from the 8th millennium BC<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[54]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The earliest attested archaeological artifacts in Iran, like those excavated at <a href="/wiki/Kashafrud" title="Kashafrud">Kashafrud</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ganj_Par" title="Ganj Par">Ganj Par</a> in northern Iran, confirm a human presence in Iran since the <a href="/wiki/Lower_Paleolithic" title="Lower Paleolithic">Lower Paleolithic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[55]</a></sup> Iran's <a href="/wiki/Neanderthal" title="Neanderthal">Neanderthal</a> artifacts from the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Paleolithic" title="Middle Paleolithic">Middle Paleolithic</a> have been found mainly in the <a href="/wiki/Zagros_Mountains" title="Zagros Mountains">Zagros</a> region, at sites such as <a href="/wiki/Warwasi" title="Warwasi">Warwasi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yafteh" title="Yafteh">Yafteh</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Museum_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Museum-58">[56]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[57]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (July 2013)">page&nbsp;needed</span></a></i>]</sup> From the 10th to the seventh millennium BC, early agricultural communities began to flourish in and around the Zagros region in western Iran, including <a href="/wiki/Chogha_Golan" title="Chogha Golan">Chogha Golan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[59]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chogha_Bonut" title="Chogha Bonut">Chogha Bonut</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[60]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[61]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Chogha_Mish" title="Chogha Mish">Chogha Mish</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[62]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[63]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (July 2013)">page&nbsp;needed</span></a></i>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-xinhuaciv_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-xinhuaciv-66">[64]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The occupation of grouped hamlets in the area of <a href="/wiki/Susa" title="Susa">Susa</a>, as determined by <a href="/wiki/Radiocarbon_dating" title="Radiocarbon dating">radiocarbon dating</a>, ranges from 4395–3955 to 3680-3490 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[65]</a></sup> There are dozens of prehistoric sites across the Iranian Plateau, pointing to the existence of ancient cultures and urban settlements in the fourth millennium BC.<sup id="cite_ref-xinhuaciv_66-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-xinhuaciv-66">[64]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-iran-daily_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iran-daily-68">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-iranian.ws_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iranian.ws-69">[67]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a>, the territory of present-day Iran was home to several civilizations, including <a href="/wiki/Elam" title="Elam">Elam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jiroft_culture" title="Jiroft culture">Jiroft</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Zayandeh_River_Culture" title="Zayandeh River Culture">Zayanderud</a>. Elam, the most prominent of these civilizations, developed in the southwest alongside those in <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>, and continued its existence until the emergence of the Iranian empires. The advent of writing in Elam was paralleled to <a href="/wiki/Sumerian_language#Writing_system" title="Sumerian language">Sumer</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Elamite_cuneiform" title="Elamite cuneiform">Elamite cuneiform</a> was developed since the third millennium BC.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[68]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>From the 34th to the 20th century BC, northwestern Iran was part of the <a href="/wiki/Kura-Araxes_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Kura-Araxes culture">Kura-Araxes culture</a>, which stretched into the neighboring <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>. Since the earliest second millennium BC, <a href="/wiki/Assyria" title="Assyria">Assyrians</a> settled in swaths of western Iran and incorporated the region into their territories. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_antiquity">Classical antiquity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Medes" title="Medes">Median Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian Empire</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sasanian Empire</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_migrations" title="Indo-European migrations">Indo-European migrations</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Medes_and_Persians_at_eastern_stairs_of_the_Apadana,_Persepolis.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Medes_and_Persians_at_eastern_stairs_of_the_Apadana%2C_Persepolis.JPG/220px-Medes_and_Persians_at_eastern_stairs_of_the_Apadana%2C_Persepolis.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Medes_and_Persians_at_eastern_stairs_of_the_Apadana%2C_Persepolis.JPG/330px-Medes_and_Persians_at_eastern_stairs_of_the_Apadana%2C_Persepolis.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Medes_and_Persians_at_eastern_stairs_of_the_Apadana%2C_Persepolis.JPG/440px-Medes_and_Persians_at_eastern_stairs_of_the_Apadana%2C_Persepolis.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3072"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Medes_and_Persians_at_eastern_stairs_of_the_Apadana,_Persepolis.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A <a href="/wiki/Bas-relief" class="mw-redirect" title="Bas-relief">bas-relief</a> at <a href="/wiki/Persepolis" title="Persepolis">Persepolis</a>, depicting the united <a href="/wiki/Medes" title="Medes">Medes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Persian people">Persians</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>By the second millennium BC, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_ancient_Iranian_peoples" title="List of ancient Iranian peoples">ancient Iranian peoples</a> arrived in what is now Iran from the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Steppe" title="Eurasian Steppe">Eurasian Steppe</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[69]</a></sup> rivaling the native settlers of the region.<sup id="cite_ref-Panshin_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Panshin-72">[70]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[71]</a></sup> As the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_peoples" title="Iranian peoples">Iranians</a> dispersed into the wider area of <a href="/wiki/Greater_Iran" title="Greater Iran">Greater Iran</a> and beyond, the boundaries of modern-day Iran were dominated by <a href="/wiki/Medes" title="Medes">Median</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Persian people">Persian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Parthia" title="Parthia">Parthian</a> tribes. </p>
      <p>From the late 10th to the late seventh century BC, the Iranian peoples, together with the "pre-Iranian" kingdoms, fell under the domination of the <a href="/wiki/Assyria" title="Assyria">Assyrian Empire</a>, based in northern <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Georges_Roux_–_Ancient_Iraq_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Georges_Roux_–_Ancient_Iraq-74">[72]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (November 2020)">page&nbsp;needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Under king <a href="/wiki/Cyaxares" title="Cyaxares">Cyaxares</a>, the Medes and Persians entered into an alliance with <a href="/wiki/Babylonia" title="Babylonia">Babylonian</a> ruler <a href="/wiki/Nabopolassar" title="Nabopolassar">Nabopolassar</a>, as well as the fellow Iranian <a href="/wiki/Scythians" title="Scythians">Scythians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cimmerians" title="Cimmerians">Cimmerians</a>, and together they attacked the Assyrian Empire. The civil war ravaged the Assyrian Empire between 616 and 605&nbsp;BC, thus freeing their respective peoples from three centuries of Assyrian rule.<sup id="cite_ref-Georges_Roux_–_Ancient_Iraq_74-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Georges_Roux_–_Ancient_Iraq-74">[72]</a></sup> The unification of the Median tribes under king <a href="/wiki/Deioces" title="Deioces">Deioces</a> in 728&nbsp;BC led to the foundation of the Median Empire which, by 612&nbsp;BC, controlled almost the entire territory of present-day Iran and eastern <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[73]</a></sup> This marked the end of the <a href="/wiki/Urartu" title="Urartu">Kingdom of Urartu</a> as well, which was subsequently conquered and dissolved.<sup id="cite_ref-Sagona2006_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sagona2006-76">[74]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[75]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pasargad_Tomb_Cyrus3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Pasargad_Tomb_Cyrus3.jpg/220px-Pasargad_Tomb_Cyrus3.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Pasargad_Tomb_Cyrus3.jpg/330px-Pasargad_Tomb_Cyrus3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Pasargad_Tomb_Cyrus3.jpg/440px-Pasargad_Tomb_Cyrus3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5996" data-file-height="4000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pasargad_Tomb_Cyrus3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Tomb of <a href="/wiki/Cyrus_the_Great" title="Cyrus the Great">Cyrus the Great</a>, founder of the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Pasargadae" title="Pasargadae">Pasargadae</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 550&nbsp;BC, <a href="/wiki/Cyrus_the_Great" title="Cyrus the Great">Cyrus the Great</a>, the son of <a href="/wiki/Mandane_of_Media" title="Mandane of Media">Mandane</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cambyses_I" title="Cambyses I">Cambyses I</a>, took over the Median Empire, and founded the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a> by unifying other city-states. The conquest of Media was a result of what is called the <i><a href="/wiki/Persian_Revolt" title="Persian Revolt">Persian Revolt</a></i>. The <a href="/wiki/Brouhaha" title="Brouhaha">brouhaha</a> was initially triggered by the actions of the Median ruler <a href="/wiki/Astyages" title="Astyages">Astyages</a>, and was quickly spread to other provinces, as they allied with the Persians. Later conquests under Cyrus and his successors expanded the empire to include <a href="/wiki/Lydia" title="Lydia">Lydia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Babylon" title="Babylon">Babylon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">Egypt</a>, parts of the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a> proper, as well as the lands to the west of the <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">Indus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oxus_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Oxus River">Oxus</a> rivers. </p>
      <p>539 BC was the year in which Persian forces defeated the Babylonian army at <a href="/wiki/Opis" title="Opis">Opis</a>, and marked the end of around four centuries of Mesopotamian domination of the region by conquering the <a href="/wiki/Neo-Babylonian_Empire" title="Neo-Babylonian Empire">Neo-Babylonian Empire</a>. Cyrus entered Babylon and presented himself as a traditional Mesopotamian monarch. Subsequent Achaemenid art and iconography reflect the influence of the new political reality in Mesopotamia. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Achaemenid_Empire_(flat_map).svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Achaemenid_Empire_%28flat_map%29.svg/220px-Achaemenid_Empire_%28flat_map%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Achaemenid_Empire_%28flat_map%29.svg/330px-Achaemenid_Empire_%28flat_map%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Achaemenid_Empire_%28flat_map%29.svg/440px-Achaemenid_Empire_%28flat_map%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="672" data-file-height="442"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Achaemenid_Empire_(flat_map).svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a> (550 BC–330 BC) around the time of <a href="/wiki/Darius_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Darius I">Darius I</a> and <a href="/wiki/Xerxes_I" title="Xerxes I">Xerxes I</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_the_Parthian_Empire_under_Mithridates_II.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Map_of_the_Parthian_Empire_under_Mithridates_II.svg/220px-Map_of_the_Parthian_Empire_under_Mithridates_II.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="122" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Map_of_the_Parthian_Empire_under_Mithridates_II.svg/330px-Map_of_the_Parthian_Empire_under_Mithridates_II.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Map_of_the_Parthian_Empire_under_Mithridates_II.svg/440px-Map_of_the_Parthian_Empire_under_Mithridates_II.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="2187" data-file-height="1217"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_the_Parthian_Empire_under_Mithridates_II.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian Empire</a> (247 BC–224 AD) in 94 BC at its greatest extent, during the reign of Mithridates II
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>At its greatest extent, the Achaemenid Empire included territories of modern-day Iran, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Republic of Azerbaijan</a> (<a href="/wiki/Arran_(Caucasus)" title="Arran (Caucasus)">Arran</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shirvan" title="Shirvan">Shirvan</a>), <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a> (<a href="/wiki/Classical_Anatolia" title="Classical Anatolia">Anatolia</a>), much of the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> coastal regions, northeastern <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a> and southern <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> (<a href="/wiki/Thrace" title="Thrace">Thrace</a>), northern Greece and <a href="/wiki/North_Macedonia" title="North Macedonia">North Macedonia</a> (<a href="/wiki/Paeonia_(kingdom)" title="Paeonia (kingdom)">Paeonia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Macedonia_(ancient_kingdom)" title="Macedonia (ancient kingdom)">Macedon</a>), <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_territories" title="Palestinian territories">Palestinian territories</a>, all significant population centers of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">ancient Egypt</a> as far west as <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">Libya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kuwait" title="Kuwait">Kuwait</a>, northern <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>, parts of the <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, Afghanistan, and much of <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>, making it the largest empire the world had yet seen.<sup id="cite_ref-book_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-book-16">[15]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>It is estimated that in 480 BC, 50 million people lived in the Achaemenid Empire.<sup id="cite_ref-1996,_p._47_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1996,_p._47-78">[76]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Cook_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cook-79">[77]</a></sup> The empire at its peak ruled over 44% of the world's population, the highest such figure for any empire in history.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[78]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Achaemenid Empire is noted for the release of the <a href="/wiki/Babylonian_captivity" title="Babylonian captivity">Jewish exiles in Babylon</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[79]</a></sup> building infrastructures such as the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Road" title="Royal Road">Royal Road</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Chapar_Khaneh" title="Chapar Khaneh">Chapar</a> (postal service), and the use of an <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Old_Aramaic_language#Imperial_Aramaic" class="mw-redirect" title="Old Aramaic language">Imperial Aramaic</a>, throughout its territories.<sup id="cite_ref-book_16-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-book-16">[15]</a></sup> The empire had a centralized, bureaucratic administration under the emperor, a large professional army, and civil services, inspiring similar developments in later empires.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-schmitt-EI-i_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-schmitt-EI-i-83">[81]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Eventual conflict on the western borders began with the <a href="/wiki/Ionian_Revolt" title="Ionian Revolt">Ionian Revolt</a>, which erupted into the <a href="/wiki/Greco-Persian_Wars" title="Greco-Persian Wars">Greco-Persian Wars</a> and continued through the first half of the fifth century BC, and ended with the withdrawal of the Achaemenids from all of the territories in the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a> proper.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoismanWorthington2011135–138,_342–345_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoismanWorthington2011135–138,_342–345-84">[82]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 334&nbsp;BC, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a> invaded the Achaemenid Empire, defeating the last Achaemenid emperor, <a href="/wiki/Darius_III" title="Darius III">Darius III</a>, at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Issus" title="Battle of Issus">Battle of Issus</a>. Following the premature death of Alexander, Iran came under the control of the <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_period" title="Hellenistic period">Hellenistic</a> <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid Empire</a>. In the middle of the second century BC, the <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian Empire</a> rose to become the main power in Iran, and the century-long geopolitical arch-rivalry between the Romans and the Parthians began, culminating in the <a href="/wiki/Roman%E2%80%93Parthian_Wars" title="Roman–Parthian Wars">Roman–Parthian Wars</a>. The Parthian Empire continued as a feudal monarchy for nearly five centuries, until 224&nbsp;CE, when it was succeeded by the <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sasanian Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[83]</a></sup> Together with their neighboring arch-rival, the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman</a>-<a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantines</a>, they made up the world's two most dominant powers at the time, for over four centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-Norman_A._Stillman_p._22_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Norman_A._Stillman_p._22-17">[16]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Byzantine_Studies_2006,_p._29_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Byzantine_Studies_2006,_p._29-18">[17]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Sassanid_reliefs_at_Taq_e_Bostan.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Sassanid_reliefs_at_Taq_e_Bostan.jpg/220px-Sassanid_reliefs_at_Taq_e_Bostan.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="224" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Sassanid_reliefs_at_Taq_e_Bostan.jpg/330px-Sassanid_reliefs_at_Taq_e_Bostan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/72/Sassanid_reliefs_at_Taq_e_Bostan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="367" data-file-height="373"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Sassanid_reliefs_at_Taq_e_Bostan.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Sasanian_art" title="Sasanian art">Sasanian</a> rock reliefs at <a href="/wiki/Taq_Bostan" class="mw-redirect" title="Taq Bostan">Taq Bostan</a>, in the heart of the <a href="/wiki/Zagros_Mountains" title="Zagros Mountains">Zagros Mountains</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Sasanians established an empire within the frontiers achieved by the Achaemenids, with their capital at <a href="/wiki/Ctesiphon" title="Ctesiphon">Ctesiphon</a>. Late antiquity is considered one of Iran's most influential periods, as under the Sasanians their influence reached the <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_ancient_Rome" title="Culture of ancient Rome">culture of ancient Rome</a> (and through that as far as <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-J._B._Bury,_p._109_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-J._B._Bury,_p._109-86">[84]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[85]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Africa" title="Culture of Africa">Africa</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[86]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chinese_culture" title="Chinese culture">China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_India" title="Culture of India">India</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[87]</a></sup> and played a prominent role in the formation of the medieval art of both <a href="/wiki/Medieval_art" title="Medieval art">Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Eastern_art" class="mw-redirect" title="History of Eastern art">Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Iransaga:_The_art_of_Sassanians_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Iransaga:_The_art_of_Sassanians-90">[88]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Most of the era of the Sasanian Empire was overshadowed by the <a href="/wiki/Roman%E2%80%93Persian_Wars" title="Roman–Persian Wars">Roman–Persian Wars</a>, which raged on the western borders at Anatolia, the <a href="/wiki/Western_Caucasus" title="Western Caucasus">Western Caucasus</a>, Mesopotamia, and the <a href="/wiki/Levant" title="Levant">Levant</a>, for over 700 years. These wars ultimately exhausted both the Romans and the Sasanians and led to the defeat of both by the Muslim invasion.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Throughout the Achaemenid, Parthian, and Sasanian eras, several offshoots of the Iranian dynasties established <a href="/wiki/Eponymous" class="mw-redirect" title="Eponymous">eponymous</a> branches in Anatolia and the Caucasus, including the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Pontus" title="Kingdom of Pontus">Pontic Kingdom</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mihranids" title="Mihranids">Mihranids</a>, and the Arsacid dynasties of <a href="/wiki/Arsacid_dynasty_of_Armenia" title="Arsacid dynasty of Armenia">Armenia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arsacid_dynasty_of_Iberia" title="Arsacid dynasty of Iberia">Iberia</a> (<a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Arsacid_dynasty_of_Caucasian_Albania" title="Arsacid dynasty of Caucasian Albania">Caucasian Albania</a> (present-day <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Republic of Azerbaijan</a> and southern <a href="/wiki/Dagestan" title="Dagestan">Dagestan</a>).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Medieval_period">Medieval period</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Persia" title="Muslim conquest of Persia">Muslim conquest of Persia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Iran" class="mw-redirect" title="Medieval Iran">Medieval Iran</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The prolonged <a href="/wiki/Byzantine%E2%80%93Sasanian_wars" class="mw-redirect" title="Byzantine–Sasanian wars">Byzantine–Sasanian wars</a>, most importantly the climactic <a href="/wiki/Byzantine%E2%80%93Sasanian_War_of_602%E2%80%93628" title="Byzantine–Sasanian War of 602–628">war of 602–628</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Sasanian_Empire#Social_problems" class="mw-redirect" title="Fall of the Sasanian Empire">social conflict within the Sasanian Empire</a>, opened the way for an Arab invasion of Iran in the seventh century.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[89]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[90]</a></sup> The empire was initially defeated by the <a href="/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate" title="Rashidun Caliphate">Rashidun Caliphate</a>, which was succeeded by the <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad Caliphate</a>, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">Abbasid Caliphate</a>. A prolonged and gradual process of state-imposed <a href="/wiki/Islamization_of_Iran" title="Islamization of Iran">Islamization</a> followed, which targeted Iran's then Zoroastrian majority and included religious persecution,<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[91]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[92]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[93]</a></sup> demolition of libraries<sup id="cite_ref-bbc_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-96">[94]</a></sup> and fire temples,<sup id="cite_ref-khan29_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-khan29-97">[95]</a></sup> a special tax penalty ("<a href="/wiki/Jizya" title="Jizya">jizya</a>"),<sup id="cite_ref-Hashemi2008_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hashemi2008-98">[96]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[97]</a></sup> and language shift.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[98]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[99]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 750, the Abbasids overthrew the Umayyads.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[100]</a></sup> Arabs Muslims and Persians of all strata made up the rebel army, which was united by the converted Persian Muslim, <a href="/wiki/Abu_Muslim" title="Abu Muslim">Abu Muslim</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-wsu_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wsu-103">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[102]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[103]</a></sup> In their struggle for power, the society in their times gradually became cosmopolitan and the old Arab simplicity and aristocratic dignity, bearing and prestige were lost. Persians and Turks began to replace the Arabs in most fields. The fusion of the Arab nobility with the subject races, the practice of polygamy and concubinage, made for a social amalgam wherein loyalties became uncertain and a hierarchy of officials emerged, a bureaucracy at first Persian and later Turkish which decreased Abbasid prestige and power for good.<sup id="cite_ref-Mahmud1988_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mahmud1988-106">[104]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After two centuries of Arab rule, semi-independent and independent Iranian kingdoms—including the <a href="/wiki/Tahirid_dynasty" title="Tahirid dynasty">Tahirids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saffarid_dynasty" title="Saffarid dynasty">Saffarids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samanid_Empire" title="Samanid Empire">Samanids</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Buyid_dynasty" title="Buyid dynasty">Buyids</a>—began to appear on the fringes of the declining Abbasid Caliphate.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Hafez_880714_095.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Hafez_880714_095.jpg/220px-Hafez_880714_095.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Hafez_880714_095.jpg/330px-Hafez_880714_095.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Hafez_880714_095.jpg/440px-Hafez_880714_095.jpg 2x" data-file-width="700" data-file-height="490"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Hafez_880714_095.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Tomb of <a href="/wiki/Hafez" title="Hafez">Hafez</a>, the medieval <a href="/wiki/Persian_literature" title="Persian literature">Persian poet</a> whose works are regarded as a pinnacle in <a href="/wiki/Persian_literature" title="Persian literature">Persian literature</a> and have left a considerable mark on later Western writers, most notably <a href="/wiki/Goethe" class="mw-redirect" title="Goethe">Goethe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thoreau" class="mw-redirect" title="Thoreau">Thoreau</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Waldo_Emerson" title="Ralph Waldo Emerson">Emerson</a><sup id="cite_ref-Paul_Kane_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Paul_Kane-107">[105]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Shafiq_Shamel_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shafiq_Shamel-108">[106]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Adineh_Khojasteh_Pour_and_Behnam_Mirza_Baba_Zadeh_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Adineh_Khojasteh_Pour_and_Behnam_Mirza_Baba_Zadeh-109">[107]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The blossoming <a href="/wiki/Persian_literature" title="Persian literature">literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iranian_philosophy" title="Iranian philosophy">philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age#Mathematics" title="Islamic Golden Age">mathematics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Iranian_medicine" title="Ancient Iranian medicine">medicine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age#Astronomy" title="Islamic Golden Age">astronomy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iranian_art" class="mw-redirect" title="Iranian art">art</a> of Iran became major elements in the formation of a new age for the Iranian civilization, during a period known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age" title="Islamic Golden Age">Islamic Golden Age</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[108]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[109]</a></sup> The Islamic Golden Age reached its peak by the 10th and 11th centuries, during which Iran was the main theater of scientific activities.<sup id="cite_ref-rnfrye_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rnfrye-112">[110]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The cultural revival that began in the Abbasid period led to a resurfacing of the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_nationalism" title="Iranian nationalism">Iranian national identity</a>; thus, the attempts of <a href="/wiki/Arabization" title="Arabization">Arabization</a> never succeeded in Iran.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The <a href="/wiki/Shu%27ubiyya" title="Shu'ubiyya">Shu'ubiyya</a> movement became a catalyst for Iranians to regain independence in their relations with the Arab invaders.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[111]</a></sup> The most notable effect of this movement was the continuation of the Persian language attested to the works of the epic poet <a href="/wiki/Ferdowsi" title="Ferdowsi">Ferdowsi</a>, now considered the most prominent figure in Iranian literature.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Toghrol_Tower_in_Ray.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Toghrol_Tower_in_Ray.jpg/220px-Toghrol_Tower_in_Ray.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="235" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Toghrol_Tower_in_Ray.jpg/330px-Toghrol_Tower_in_Ray.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Toghrol_Tower_in_Ray.jpg/440px-Toghrol_Tower_in_Ray.jpg 2x" data-file-width="886" data-file-height="945"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Toghrol_Tower_in_Ray.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Tughrul_Tower" class="mw-redirect" title="Tughrul Tower">Tuğrul Tower</a>, a 12th-century monument at <a href="/wiki/Rey,_Iran" class="mw-redirect" title="Rey, Iran">Rhages</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
