      <p>Myths play a crucial part in Iranian culture, and understanding of them is increased when they are considered within the context of actual events in Iranian history. The geography of Greater Iran, a vast area covering present-day Iran, the Caucasus, Anatolia, Mesopotamia and Central Asia, with its high mountain ranges, plays the main role in much of Iranian mythology. </p>
      <p>Tenth-century Persian poet <a href="/wiki/Ferdowsi" title="Ferdowsi">Ferdowsi</a>'s long <a href="/wiki/Epic_poetry" title="Epic poetry">epic poem</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Shahnameh" title="Shahnameh">Šāhnāme</a></i> ("Book of Kings"), which is for the most part based on <i>Xwadāynāmag</i>, a <a href="/wiki/Middle_Persian" title="Middle Persian">Middle Persian</a> compilation of the history of Iranian kings and heroes from mythical times down to the reign of <a href="/wiki/Khosrow_II" title="Khosrow II">Chosroes II</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446">[444]</a></sup> is considered the <a href="/wiki/National_epic" title="National epic">national epic</a> of Iran. It draws heavily on the stories and characters of the Zoroastrian tradition, from the texts of the <a href="/wiki/Avesta" title="Avesta">Avesta</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Denkard" title="Denkard">Denkard</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Bundahishn" title="Bundahishn">Bundahishn</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Iran" title="Music of Iran">Music of Iran</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Iran is the apparent birthplace of the earliest complex instruments, dating back to the third millennium BC.<sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447">[445]</a></sup> The use of both vertical and horizontal angular <a href="/wiki/Harp" title="Harp">harps</a> have been documented at the sites Madaktu and <a href="/wiki/Kul-e_Farah" title="Kul-e Farah">Kul-e Farah</a>, with the largest collection of <a href="/wiki/Elam" title="Elam">Elamite</a> instruments documented at Kul-e Farah. Multiple depictions of horizontal harps were also sculpted in Assyrian palaces, dating back between 865 and 650 BC. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Karna-Persian-Instrument-Persepolis-Museum.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Karna-Persian-Instrument-Persepolis-Museum.JPG/220px-Karna-Persian-Instrument-Persepolis-Museum.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Karna-Persian-Instrument-Persepolis-Museum.JPG/330px-Karna-Persian-Instrument-Persepolis-Museum.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Karna-Persian-Instrument-Persepolis-Museum.JPG/440px-Karna-Persian-Instrument-Persepolis-Museum.JPG 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Karna-Persian-Instrument-Persepolis-Museum.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Zurna" title="Zurna">Karna</a>, an ancient Iranian musical instrument from the 6th century BC, kept at the Persepolis Museum
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Xenophon" title="Xenophon">Xenophon</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Cyropaedia" title="Cyropaedia">Cyropaedia</a></i> mentions a great number of singing women at the court of the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a>. <a href="/wiki/Athenaeus" title="Athenaeus">Athenaeus</a> of <a href="/wiki/Naucratis" title="Naucratis">Naucratis</a>, in his <i><a href="/wiki/Deipnosophistae" title="Deipnosophistae">Deipnosophistae</a></i>, points out to the capture of Achaemenid singing girls at the court of the last Achaemenid king <a href="/wiki/Darius_III" title="Darius III">Darius III</a> (336–330 BC) by <a href="/wiki/Macedonia_(ancient_kingdom)" title="Macedonia (ancient kingdom)">Macedonian</a> general <a href="/wiki/Parmenion" title="Parmenion">Parmenion</a>. Under the <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian Empire</a>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Gusans" title="Gusans">gōsān</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Parthian_language" title="Parthian language">Parthian</a> for "minstrel") had a prominent role in the society.<sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448">[446]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Plutarch" title="Plutarch">Plutarch</a>'s <i>Life of Crassus</i> (32.3), they praised their national heroes and ridiculed their Roman rivals. Likewise, <a href="/wiki/Strabo" title="Strabo">Strabo</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Geographica" title="Geographica">Geographica</a></i> reports that the Parthian youth were taught songs about "the deeds both of the gods and of the noblest men".<sup id="cite_ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449">[447]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The history of <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_music" title="Sasanian music">Sasanian music</a> is better documented than the earlier periods, and is especially more evident in Avestan texts.<sup id="cite_ref-EI-mhphi_450-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EI-mhphi-450">[448]</a></sup> By the time of <a href="/wiki/Khosrow_II" title="Khosrow II">Chosroes II</a>, the Sasanian royal court hosted a number of prominent musicians, namely Azad, <a href="/wiki/Bamshad" title="Bamshad">Bamshad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barbad" title="Barbad">Barbad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nagisa_(harpist)" title="Nagisa (harpist)">Nagisa</a>, Ramtin, and <a href="/wiki/Sarkash" title="Sarkash">Sarkash</a>. </p>
      <p>Iranian traditional musical instruments include string instruments such as <a href="/wiki/Chang_(instrument)" title="Chang (instrument)">chang</a> (<a href="/wiki/Harp" title="Harp">harp</a>), <a href="/wiki/Qanun_(instrument)" title="Qanun (instrument)">qanun</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santur" title="Santur">santur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rud" title="Rud">rud</a> (<a href="/wiki/Oud" title="Oud">oud</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barbat_(lute)" title="Barbat (lute)">barbat</a>), <a href="/wiki/Tar_(string_instrument)" title="Tar (string instrument)">tar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dutar" title="Dutar">dotar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Setar" title="Setar">setar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tanbur" title="Tanbur">tanbur</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kamancheh" title="Kamancheh">kamanche</a>, wind instruments such as <a href="/wiki/Sorna" title="Sorna">sorna</a> (<a href="/wiki/Zurna" title="Zurna">zurna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karnay" title="Karnay">karna</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Ney" title="Ney">ney</a>, and percussion instruments such as <a href="/wiki/Tonbak" class="mw-redirect" title="Tonbak">tompak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kus" title="Kus">kus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daf" title="Daf">daf</a> (<a href="/wiki/Dayereh" title="Dayereh">dayere</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Naqareh" title="Naqareh">naqare</a>. </p>
      <p>Iran's first symphony orchestra, the <a href="/wiki/Tehran_Symphony_Orchestra" title="Tehran Symphony Orchestra">Tehran Symphony Orchestra</a>, was founded by Qolam-Hoseyn Minbashian in 1933. It was reformed by <a href="/wiki/Parviz_Mahmoud" title="Parviz Mahmoud">Parviz Mahmoud</a> in 1946, and is currently Iran's oldest and largest symphony orchestra. Later, by the late 1940s, <a href="/wiki/Ruhollah_Khaleqi" title="Ruhollah Khaleqi">Ruhollah Khaleqi</a> founded the country's first national music society, and established the School of National Music in 1949.<sup id="cite_ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451">[449]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Iranian_pop_music" title="Iranian pop music">Iranian pop music</a> has its origins in the Qajar era.<sup id="cite_ref-452" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-452">[450]</a></sup> It was significantly developed since the 1950s, using indigenous instruments and forms accompanied by <a href="/wiki/Electric_guitar" title="Electric guitar">electric guitar</a> and other imported characteristics. The emergence of genres such as <a href="/wiki/Iranian_rock" title="Iranian rock">rock</a> in the 1960s and <a href="/wiki/Iranian_hip_hop" title="Iranian hip hop">hip hop</a> in the 2000s also resulted in major movements and influences in Iranian music.<sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453">[451]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-454" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-454">[452]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-455" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-455">[453]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456">[454]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Theater">Theater</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Persian_theater" class="mw-redirect" title="Persian theater">Persian theater</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persian_dance" class="mw-redirect" title="Persian dance">Persian dance</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:RudakiHall.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/RudakiHall.jpg/220px-RudakiHall.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="138" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/RudakiHall.jpg/330px-RudakiHall.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/RudakiHall.jpg/440px-RudakiHall.jpg 2x" data-file-width="639" data-file-height="400"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:RudakiHall.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Roudaki_Hall" class="mw-redirect" title="Roudaki Hall">Roudaki Hall</a>, constructed between 1957 and 1967 in <a href="/wiki/Tehran" title="Tehran">Tehran</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The earliest recorded representations of dancing figures within Iran were found in prehistoric sites such as Tepe Sialk and Tepe Mūsīān.<sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457">[455]</a></sup> The oldest Iranian initiation of theater and the phenomena of acting can be traced in the ancient epic ceremonial theaters such as <i>Sug-e Siāvuš</i> ("mourning of <a href="/wiki/Siy%C3%A2vash" title="Siyâvash">Siāvaš</a>"), as well as dances and theater narrations of Iranian mythological tales reported by <a href="/wiki/Herodotus" title="Herodotus">Herodotus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Xenophon" title="Xenophon">Xenophon</a>. </p>
      <p>Iran's traditional theatrical genres include Baqqāl-bāzi ("grocer play", a form of slapstick comedy), Ruhowzi (or <i>Taxt-howzi</i>, comedy performed over a courtyard pool covered with boards), Siāh-bāzi (in which the central comedian appears in blackface), Sāye-bāzi (<a href="/wiki/Shadow_play" title="Shadow play">shadow play</a>), Xeyme-šab-bāzi (<a href="/wiki/Marionette" title="Marionette">marionette</a>), and Arusak-bāzi (<a href="/wiki/Puppetry" title="Puppetry">puppetry</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Ta%27zieh" title="Ta'zieh">Ta'zie</a> (religious tragedy plays).<sup id="cite_ref-458" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-458">[456]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Before the 1979 Revolution, the Iranian national stage had become a famous performing scene for known international artists and troupes,<sup id="cite_ref-459" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-459">[457]</a></sup> with the <a href="/wiki/Roudaki_Hall" class="mw-redirect" title="Roudaki Hall">Roudaki Hall</a> of Tehran constructed to function as the national stage for <a href="/wiki/Opera" title="Opera">opera</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ballet" title="Ballet">ballet</a>. Opened on 26 October 1967, the hall is home to the <a href="/wiki/Tehran_Symphony_Orchestra" title="Tehran Symphony Orchestra">Tehran Symphony Orchestra</a>, the Tehran Opera Orchestra, and the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_National_Ballet_Company" title="Iranian National Ballet Company">Iranian National Ballet Company</a>, and was officially renamed <i>Vahdat Hall</i> after the 1979 Revolution. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Loris_Tjeknavorian" title="Loris Tjeknavorian">Loris Tjeknavorian</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Rostam_and_Sohrab_(opera)" title="Rostam and Sohrab (opera)">Rostam and Sohrab</a></i>, based on the tragedy of <i><a href="/wiki/Rostam_and_Sohrab" title="Rostam and Sohrab">Rostam and Sohrab</a></i> from <a href="/wiki/Ferdowsi" title="Ferdowsi">Ferdowsi</a>'s epic poem <i><a href="/wiki/Shahnameh" title="Shahnameh">Šāhnāme</a></i>, is an example of opera with Persian <a href="/wiki/Libretto" title="Libretto">libretto</a>. Tjeknavorian, a celebrated <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Armenians" title="Iranian Armenians">Iranian Armenian</a> composer and conductor, composed it in 25 years, and it was finally performed for the first time at Tehran's Roudaki Hall, with <a href="/wiki/Darya_Dadvar" title="Darya Dadvar">Darya Dadvar</a> in the role of <a href="/wiki/Tahmina" title="Tahmina">Tahmina</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema_and_animation">Cinema and animation</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Iran" title="Cinema of Iran">Cinema of Iran</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Iranian_animation" title="History of Iranian animation">History of Iranian animation</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Vase_animation.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Vase_animation.svg/220px-Vase_animation.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="39" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Vase_animation.svg/330px-Vase_animation.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Vase_animation.svg/440px-Vase_animation.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="2384" data-file-height="426"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Vase_animation.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Reproduction of the 3rd-millennium BC goblet from southeastern Iran, possibly the world's oldest example of animation.<sup id="cite_ref-460" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-460">[458]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>A third-millennium BC earthen goblet discovered at the <a href="/wiki/Shahr-e_Sukhteh" title="Shahr-e Sukhteh">Burnt City</a>, a Bronze Age urban settlement in southeastern Iran, depicts what could possibly be the world's oldest example of animation. The artifact, associated with <a href="/wiki/Jiroft_culture" title="Jiroft culture">Jiroft</a>, bears five sequential images depicting a wild goat jumping up to eat the leaves of a tree.<sup id="cite_ref-461" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-461">[459]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-462" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-462">[460]</a></sup> The earliest attested Iranian examples of visual representations, however, are traced back to the bas-reliefs of Persepolis, the ritual center of the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a>. The figures at Persepolis remain bound by the rules of grammar and syntax of visual language.<sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463">[461]</a></sup> The Iranian visual arts reached a pinnacle by the <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sasanian era</a>, and several works from this period have been found to articulate movements and actions in a highly sophisticated manner. It is even possible to see a progenitor of the cinematic close-up shot in one of these works of art, which shows a wounded wild pig escaping from the hunting ground.<sup id="cite_ref-horschamp1_464-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-horschamp1-464">[462]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Behrouz_Vossoughi.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Behrouz_Vossoughi.jpg/170px-Behrouz_Vossoughi.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="226" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Behrouz_Vossoughi.jpg/255px-Behrouz_Vossoughi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Behrouz_Vossoughi.jpg/340px-Behrouz_Vossoughi.jpg 2x" data-file-width="435" data-file-height="579"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Behrouz_Vossoughi.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Behrouz_Vossoughi" title="Behrouz Vossoughi">Behrouz Vossoughi</a>, a well-known Iranian actor who has appeared in more than 90 films
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kiarostami-1940.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Kiarostami-1940.jpg/170px-Kiarostami-1940.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="176" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Kiarostami-1940.jpg/255px-Kiarostami-1940.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b6/Kiarostami-1940.jpg 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="310"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kiarostami-1940.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Abbas_Kiarostami" title="Abbas Kiarostami">Abbas Kiarostami</a> (1940–2016), an acclaimed Iranian film director
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>By the early 20th century, the five-year-old industry of cinema came to Iran. The first Iranian filmmaker was probably <a href="/wiki/Mirza_Ebrahim_Khan_Akkas_Bashi" title="Mirza Ebrahim Khan Akkas Bashi">Mirza Ebrahim (Akkas Bashi)</a>, the court photographer of <a href="/wiki/Mozaffar_ad-Din_Shah_Qajar" title="Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar">Mozaffar-ed-Din Shah</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Qajar_dynasty" title="Qajar dynasty">Qajar dynasty</a>. Mirza Ebrahim obtained a camera and filmed the Qajar ruler's visit to Europe. Later in 1904, <a href="/wiki/Mirza_Ebrahim_Khan_Sahhafbashi" title="Mirza Ebrahim Khan Sahhafbashi">Mirza Ebrahim (Sahhaf Bashi)</a>, a businessman, opened the first public movie theater in Tehran.<sup id="cite_ref-massoudmehrabi1_465-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-massoudmehrabi1-465">[463]</a></sup> After him, several others like Russi Khan, Ardeshir Khan, and Ali Vakili tried to establish new movie theaters in Tehran. Until the early 1930s, there were around 15 cinema theaters in Tehran and 11 in other provinces.<sup id="cite_ref-horschamp1_464-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-horschamp1-464">[462]</a></sup> The first Iranian feature film, <i><a href="/wiki/Abi_and_Rabi" title="Abi and Rabi">Abi and Rabi</a></i>, was a silent comedy directed by <a href="/wiki/Ovanes_Ohanian" title="Ovanes Ohanian">Ovanes Ohanian</a> in 1930. The first sounded one, <i><a href="/wiki/Lor_Girl" title="Lor Girl">Lor Girl</a></i>, was produced by <a href="/wiki/Ardeshir_Irani" title="Ardeshir Irani">Ardeshir Irani</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abdolhossein_Sepanta" title="Abdolhossein Sepanta">Abd-ol-Hosein Sepanta</a> in 1932. </p>
      <p>Iran's animation industry began by the 1950s, and was followed by the establishment of the influential <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_the_Intellectual_Development_of_Children_and_Young_Adults" title="Institute for the Intellectual Development of Children and Young Adults">Institute for the Intellectual Development of Children and Young Adults</a> in January 1965.<sup id="cite_ref-466" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-466">[464]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-467" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-467">[465]</a></sup> The 1960s was a significant decade for Iranian cinema, with 25 commercial films produced annually on average throughout the early 60s, increasing to 65 by the end of the decade. The majority of the production focused on melodrama and thrillers. With the screening of the films <i><a href="/wiki/Qeysar_(film)" title="Qeysar (film)">Qeysar</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Cow_(1969_film)" title="The Cow (1969 film)">The Cow</a></i>, directed by <a href="/wiki/Masoud_Kimiai" title="Masoud Kimiai">Masoud Kimiai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dariush_Mehrjui" title="Dariush Mehrjui">Dariush Mehrjui</a> respectively in 1969, alternative films set out to establish their status in the film industry and <a href="/wiki/Bahram_Beyzai" title="Bahram Beyzai">Bahram Beyzai</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Downpour_(film)" title="Downpour (film)">Downpour</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/Nasser_Taghvai" title="Nasser Taghvai">Nasser Taghvai</a>'s <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tranquility_in_the_Presence_of_Others&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tranquility in the Presence of Others (page does not exist)">Tranquility in the Presence of Others</a></i> followed soon. Attempts to organize a film festival, which had begun in 1954 within the framework of the Golrizan Festival, resulted in the festival of Sepas in 1969. The endeavors also resulted in the formation of the Tehran's World Film Festival in 1973.<sup id="cite_ref-Esfandiary2012_468-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Esfandiary2012-468">[466]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the Revolution of 1979, and following the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Cultural_Revolution" title="Iranian Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a>, a new age emerged in Iranian cinema, starting with <i>Long Live!</i> by <a href="/wiki/Khosrow_Sinai" title="Khosrow Sinai">Khosrow Sinai</a> and followed by many other directors, such as <a href="/wiki/Abbas_Kiarostami" title="Abbas Kiarostami">Abbas Kiarostami</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jafar_Panahi" title="Jafar Panahi">Jafar Panahi</a>. Kiarostami, an acclaimed Iranian director, planted Iran firmly on the map of world cinema when he won the <a href="/wiki/Palme_d%27Or" title="Palme d'Or">Palme d'Or</a> for <i><a href="/wiki/Taste_of_Cherry" title="Taste of Cherry">Taste of Cherry</a></i> in 1997.<sup id="cite_ref-Dabashi2007_469-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dabashi2007-469">[467]</a></sup> The continuous presence of Iranian films in prestigious international festivals, such as the <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Venice_Film_Festival" title="Venice Film Festival">Venice Film Festival</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Berlin_International_Film_Festival" title="Berlin International Film Festival">Berlin International Film Festival</a>, attracted world attention to Iranian masterpieces.<sup id="cite_ref-DecherneyAtwood2014_470-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DecherneyAtwood2014-470">[468]</a></sup> In 2006, six Iranian films, of six different styles, represented Iranian cinema at the Berlin International Film Festival. Critics considered this a remarkable event in the history of Iranian cinema.<sup id="cite_ref-471" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-471">[469]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-472" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-472">[470]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Asghar_Farhadi" title="Asghar Farhadi">Asghar Farhadi</a>, a well-known Iranian director, has received a <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="Golden Globe Award">Golden Globe Award</a> and two <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="Academy Award">Academy Awards</a>, representing Iran for Best Foreign Language Film in 2012 and 2017. In 2012, he was named as one of the 100 Most Influential People in the world by the American news magazine <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Observances">Observances</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_festivals_in_Iran" title="List of festivals in Iran">List of festivals in Iran</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:7SEEN_89.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/7SEEN_89.jpg/220px-7SEEN_89.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="198" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/7SEEN_89.jpg/330px-7SEEN_89.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/7SEEN_89.jpg/440px-7SEEN_89.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1199" data-file-height="1077"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:7SEEN_89.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Haft-Seen" class="mw-redirect" title="Haft-Seen">Haft-Seen</a>, a customary of <a href="/wiki/Nowruz" title="Nowruz">Nowruz</a>, the Iranian New Year
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Iran's official <a href="/wiki/New_Year" title="New Year">New Year</a> begins with <a href="/wiki/Nowruz" title="Nowruz">Nowruz</a>, an ancient Iranian tradition celebrated annually on the <a href="/wiki/Equinox" title="Equinox">vernal equinox</a>. It is enjoyed by people adhering to different religions, but is considered a holiday for the Zoroastrians. It was registered on the <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>'s list of <a href="/wiki/Masterpieces_of_the_Oral_and_Intangible_Heritage_of_Humanity" title="Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity">Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity</a> in 2009,<sup id="cite_ref-Unesco.org_November_29_2015c_473-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Unesco.org_November_29_2015c-473">[471]</a></sup> described as the <i>Persian New Year</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-474" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-474">[472]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-475" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-475">[473]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476">[474]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477">[475]</a></sup> shared with a number of other countries in which it has historically been celebrated. </p>
      <p>On the eve of the last Wednesday of the preceding year, as a prelude to Nowruz, the ancient festival of <a href="/wiki/Chaharshanbe_Suri" title="Chaharshanbe Suri">Čāršanbe Suri</a> celebrates <a href="/wiki/Atar" title="Atar">Ātar</a> ("fire") by performing rituals such as jumping over <a href="/wiki/Bonfire" title="Bonfire">bonfires</a> and lighting off <a href="/wiki/Firecracker" title="Firecracker">firecrackers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fireworks" title="Fireworks">fireworks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-478" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-478">[476]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-479" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-479">[477]</a></sup> The Nowruz celebrations last by the end of the 13th day of the Iranian year (<a href="/wiki/Farvardin" title="Farvardin">Farvardin</a> 13, usually coincided with 1<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>or 2<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>April), celebrating the festival of <a href="/wiki/Sizdah_Be-dar" title="Sizdah Be-dar">Sizdebedar</a>, during which the people traditionally go outdoors to <a href="/wiki/Picnic" title="Picnic">picnic</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Yald%C4%81_Night" title="Yaldā Night">Yaldā</a>, another nationally celebrated ancient tradition,<sup id="cite_ref-480" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-480">[478]</a></sup> commemorates the ancient goddess <a href="/wiki/Mithra" title="Mithra">Mithra</a> and marks the longest night of the year on the eve of the <a href="/wiki/Winter_solstice" title="Winter solstice">winter solstice</a> (<i lang="fa-Latn" title="Persian-language romanization">čelle ye zemestān</i>; usually falling on 20 or 21 December),<sup id="cite_ref-481" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-481">[479]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-482" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-482">[480]</a></sup> during which families gather together to recite poetry and eat fruits—particularly the red fruits watermelon and <a href="/wiki/Pomegranate" title="Pomegranate">pomegranate</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Mixed_nuts" title="Mixed nuts">mixed nuts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-483" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-483">[481]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-484" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-484">[482]</a></sup> In some regions of the provinces of <a href="/wiki/Mazandaran_Province" title="Mazandaran Province">Mazanderan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Markazi_Province" title="Markazi Province">Markazi</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-485" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-485">[483]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-486" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-486">[484]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-487" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-487">[485]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-488" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-488">[486]</a></sup> there is also the <a href="/wiki/Summer_solstice" title="Summer solstice">midsummer</a> festival of <a href="/wiki/Tirgan" title="Tirgan">Tirgān</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-489" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-489">[487]</a></sup> which is observed on <a href="/wiki/Tir_(month)" title="Tir (month)">Tir</a> 13 (2 or 3<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>July) as a celebration of water.<sup id="cite_ref-490" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-490">[488]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-491" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-491">[489]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Alongside the ancient Iranian celebrations, Islamic annual events such as <a href="/wiki/Ramadan" title="Ramadan">Ramezān</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eid_al-Fitr" title="Eid al-Fitr">Eid e Fetr</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ashura" title="Ashura">Ruz e Āšurā</a> are marked by the country's large Muslim population, Christian traditions such as <a href="/wiki/Christmas" title="Christmas">Noel</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-492" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-492">[490]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lent" title="Lent">Čelle ye Ruze</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Easter" title="Easter">Eid e Pāk</a><sup id="cite_ref-493" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-493">[491]</a></sup> are observed by the Christian communities, Jewish traditions such as <a href="/wiki/Purim" title="Purim">Purim</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-494" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-494">[492]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hanukkah" title="Hanukkah">Hanukā</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-495" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-495">[493]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Passover" title="Passover">Eid e Fatir</a> (Pesah)<sup id="cite_ref-496" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-496">[494]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-497" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-497">[495]</a></sup> are observed by the Jewish communities, and Zoroastrian traditions such as <a href="/wiki/Sadeh" title="Sadeh">Sade</a><sup id="cite_ref-498" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-498">[496]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Mehregan" title="Mehregan">Mehrgān</a> are observed by the Zoroastrians. </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_holidays">Public holidays</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Iran" title="Public holidays in Iran">Public holidays in Iran</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Iranian_calendars" title="Iranian calendars">Iranian calendars</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Iran's <a href="/wiki/Civil_calendar" title="Civil calendar">official calendar</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Solar_Hijri_calendar" title="Solar Hijri calendar">Solar Hejri calendar</a>, beginning at the <a href="/wiki/March_equinox" title="March equinox">vernal equinox</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Hemisphere" title="Northern Hemisphere">Northern Hemisphere</a>, which was first enacted by the Iranian Parliament on 31 March 1925.<sup id="cite_ref-Calenica_499-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Calenica-499">[497]</a></sup> Each of the 12 months of the Solar Hejri calendar correspond with a <a href="/wiki/Astrological_sign" title="Astrological sign">zodiac sign</a>, and the length of each year is absolutely solar.<sup id="cite_ref-Calenica_499-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Calenica-499">[497]</a></sup> The months are named after the ancient Iranian months,<sup id="cite_ref-Calenica_499-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Calenica-499">[497]</a></sup> namely <a href="/wiki/Farvardin" title="Farvardin">Farvardin</a> (<a href="/wiki/Fravashi" title="Fravashi"><i lang="ae-Latn" title="Avestan-language romanization">Fravaši</i></a>), <a href="/wiki/Ordibehesht" title="Ordibehesht">Ordibehešt</a> (<a href="/wiki/Asha" title="Asha"><i lang="ae-Latn" title="Avestan-language romanization">Aša Vahišta</i></a>), <a href="/wiki/Khordad" title="Khordad">Xordād</a> (<a href="/wiki/Haurvatat" title="Haurvatat"><i lang="ae-Latn" title="Avestan-language romanization">Haurvatāt</i></a>), <a href="/wiki/Tir_(month)" title="Tir (month)">Tir</a> (<a href="/wiki/Tishtrya" title="Tishtrya"><i lang="ae-Latn" title="Avestan-language romanization">Tištrya</i></a>), <a href="/wiki/Mordad" title="Mordad">Amordād</a> (<a href="/wiki/Ameretat" title="Ameretat"><i lang="ae-Latn" title="Avestan-language romanization">Amərətāt</i></a>), <a href="/wiki/Shahrivar" title="Shahrivar">Šahrivar</a> (<a href="/wiki/Kshatra_Vairya" title="Kshatra Vairya"><i lang="ae-Latn" title="Avestan-language romanization">Xšaθra Vairya</i></a>), <a href="/wiki/Mehr_(month)" title="Mehr (month)">Mehr</a> (<a href="/wiki/Mithra" title="Mithra"><i lang="ae-Latn" title="Avestan-language romanization">Miθra</i></a>), <a href="/wiki/Aban_(month)" title="Aban (month)">Ābān</a> (<a href="/wiki/Aban" title="Aban"><i lang="ae-Latn" title="Avestan-language romanization">Āpō</i></a>), <a href="/wiki/Azar" title="Azar">Āzar</a> (<a href="/wiki/Atar" title="Atar"><i lang="ae-Latn" title="Avestan-language romanization">Ātar</i></a>), <a href="/wiki/Dey_(month)" title="Dey (month)">Dey</a> (<a href="/wiki/Ahura_Mazda" title="Ahura Mazda"><i lang="ae-Latn" title="Avestan-language romanization">Daθuš</i></a>), <a href="/wiki/Bahman" title="Bahman">Bahman</a> (<a href="/wiki/Vohu_Manah" title="Vohu Manah"><i lang="ae-Latn" title="Avestan-language romanization">Vohu Manah</i></a>), and <a href="/wiki/Esfand" title="Esfand">Esfand</a> (<a href="/wiki/Spenta_Armaiti" title="Spenta Armaiti"><i lang="ae-Latn" title="Avestan-language romanization">Spəntā Ārmaiti</i></a>). </p>
      <p>Alternatively, the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Lunar Hejri calendar</a> is used to indicate Islamic events, and the <a href="/wiki/Gregorian_calendar" title="Gregorian calendar">Gregorian calendar</a> remarks the international events. </p>
      <p>Legal public holidays based on the Iranian solar calendar include the cultural celebrations of Nowruz (<a href="/wiki/Farvardin" title="Farvardin">Farvardin</a> 1–4; 21–24 March) and Sizdebedar (<a href="/wiki/Farvardin" title="Farvardin">Farvardin</a> 13; 2<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>April), and the political events of <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Islamic_Republic_Day" title="Iranian Islamic Republic Day">Islamic Republic Day</a> (<a href="/wiki/Farvardin" title="Farvardin">Farvardin</a> 12; 1<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>April), the death of <a href="/wiki/Ruhollah_Khomeini" title="Ruhollah Khomeini">Ruhollah Khomeini</a> (<a href="/wiki/Khordad" title="Khordad">Khordad</a> 14; 4<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>June), the <a href="/wiki/5_June_1963,_demonstrations_in_Iran" class="mw-redirect" title="5 June 1963, demonstrations in Iran">Khordad 15 event</a> (<a href="/wiki/Khordad" title="Khordad">Khordad</a> 15; 5<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>June), the anniversary of the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Revolution" title="Iranian Revolution">1979 Revolution</a> (<a href="/wiki/Bahman" title="Bahman">Bahman</a> 22; 10 February), and <a href="/wiki/Nationalization_of_the_Iranian_oil_industry" title="Nationalization of the Iranian oil industry">Oil Nationalization Day</a> (<a href="/wiki/Esfand" title="Esfand">Esfand</a> 29; 19 March).<sup id="cite_ref-irmys_500-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-irmys-500">[498]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Lunar Islamic public holidays include Tasua (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Muharram</a> 9; 30 September), Ashura (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Muharram</a> 10; 1<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>October), Arba'een (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Safar</a> 20; 10 November), the death of Muhammad (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Safar</a> 28; 17 November), the death of Ali al-Ridha (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Safar</a> 29 or 30; 18 November), the birthday of Muhammad (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Rabi-al-Awwal</a> 17; 6<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>December), the death of Fatimah (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Jumada-al-Thani</a> 3; 2<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>March), the birthday of Ali (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Rajab</a> 13; 10 April), Muhammad's first revelation (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Rajab</a> 27; 24 April), the birthday of Muhammad al-Mahdi (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Sha'ban</a> 15; 12 May), the death of Ali (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Ramadan</a> 21; 16 June), Eid al-Fitr (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Shawwal</a> 1–2; 26–27 June), the death of Ja'far al-Sadiq (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Shawwal</a> 25; 20 July), Eid al-Qurban (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Zulhijja</a> 10; 1<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>September), and Eid al-Qadir (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Zulhijja</a> 18; 9<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>September).<sup id="cite_ref-irmys_500-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-irmys-500">[498]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Iranian_cuisine" title="Iranian cuisine">Iranian cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kebab_Bakhtyari.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Kebab_Bakhtyari.jpg/220px-Kebab_Bakhtyari.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Kebab_Bakhtyari.jpg/330px-Kebab_Bakhtyari.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Kebab_Bakhtyari.jpg/440px-Kebab_Bakhtyari.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kebab_Bakhtyari.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Chelow_kabab" title="Chelow kabab">Chelow kabab</a> (rice and <a href="/wiki/Kebab" title="Kebab">kebab</a>), one of <a href="/wiki/Iran%27s_national_dishes" class="mw-redirect" title="Iran's national dishes">Iran's national dishes</a><sup id="cite_ref-501" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-501">[499]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-502" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-502">[500]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-503" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-503">[501]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Due to its variety of ethnic groups and the influences from the neighboring cultures, the cuisine of Iran is diverse. Herbs are frequently used, along with fruits such as plums, pomegranate, quince, prunes, apricots, and raisins. To achieve a balanced taste, characteristic flavorings such as saffron, dried lime, cinnamon, and parsley are mixed delicately and used in some special dishes. Onion and garlic are commonly used in the preparation of the accompanying course, but are also served separately during meals, either in raw or pickled form. </p>
      <p>Iranian cuisine includes a wide range of main dishes, including various types of <a href="/wiki/Kebab" title="Kebab">kebab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pilaf" title="Pilaf">pilaf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stew" title="Stew">stew</a> (<a href="/wiki/Khoresh" title="Khoresh">khoresh</a>), <a href="/wiki/Soup" title="Soup">soup</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C4%80sh" class="mw-redirect" title="Āsh">āsh</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Omelette" title="Omelette">omelette</a>. Lunch and dinner meals are commonly accompanied by side dishes such as plain <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">yogurt</a> or <a href="/wiki/Tzatziki" title="Tzatziki">mast-o-khiar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sabzi_khordan" title="Sabzi khordan">sabzi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shirazi_salad" title="Shirazi salad">salad Shirazi</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tursu" class="mw-redirect" title="Tursu">torshi</a>, and might follow dishes such as <a href="/wiki/Borani" title="Borani">borani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mirza_Ghassemi" title="Mirza Ghassemi">Mirza Qasemi</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Kashk_e_bademjan" class="mw-redirect" title="Kashk e bademjan">kashk e bademjan</a> as the appetizer. </p>
      <p>In Iranian culture, tea (<i lang="fa-Latn" title="Persian-language romanization">čāy</i>) is widely consumed.<sup id="cite_ref-504" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-504">[502]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-505" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-505">[503]</a></sup> Iran is the world's seventh major tea producer,<sup id="cite_ref-FAOSTAT_506-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FAOSTAT-506">[504]</a></sup> and a cup of tea is typically the first thing offered to a guest.<sup id="cite_ref-507" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-507">[505]</a></sup> One of Iran's most popular desserts is the <a href="/wiki/Faloodeh" title="Faloodeh">falude</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-508" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-508">[506]</a></sup> consisting of <a href="/wiki/Vermicelli" title="Vermicelli">vermicelli</a> in a <a href="/wiki/Rose_water" title="Rose water">rose water</a> syrup, which has its roots in the fourth century BC.<sup id="cite_ref-509" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-509">[507]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-510" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-510">[508]</a></sup> There is also the popular saffron ice cream, known as <i><a href="/wiki/Bastani_Sonnati" class="mw-redirect" title="Bastani Sonnati">bastani sonnati</a></i> ("traditional ice cream"),<sup id="cite_ref-511" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-511">[509]</a></sup> which is sometimes accompanied with <a href="/wiki/Carrot_juice" title="Carrot juice">carrot juice</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-512" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-512">[510]</a></sup> Iran is also famous for its <a href="/wiki/Caviar" title="Caviar">caviar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-513" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-513">[511]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Iran" title="Sport in Iran">Sport in Iran</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Dizin_ski_resort.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Dizin_ski_resort.jpg/220px-Dizin_ski_resort.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Dizin_ski_resort.jpg/330px-Dizin_ski_resort.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Dizin_ski_resort.jpg/440px-Dizin_ski_resort.jpg 2x" data-file-width="789" data-file-height="472"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Dizin_ski_resort.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Skiers at the <a href="/wiki/Dizin" title="Dizin">Dizin Ski Resort</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Iran is most likely the birthplace of <a href="/wiki/Polo" title="Polo">polo</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-514" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-514">[512]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-515" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-515">[513]</a></sup> locally known as <i>čowgān</i>, with its earliest records attributed to the ancient <a href="/wiki/Medes" title="Medes">Medes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-516" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-516">[514]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Freestyle_wrestling" title="Freestyle wrestling">Freestyle wrestling</a> is traditionally considered the <a href="/wiki/National_sport" title="National sport">national sport</a> of Iran, and the <a href="/wiki/Iran_national_freestyle_wrestling_athletes" class="mw-redirect" title="Iran national freestyle wrestling athletes">national wrestlers</a> have been world champions on many occasions. Iran's traditional wrestling, called <i><a href="/wiki/Pahlevani_and_zoorkhaneh_rituals" title="Pahlevani and zoorkhaneh rituals">košti e pahlevāni</a></i> ("heroic wrestling"), is registered on <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Intangible_Cultural_Heritage" class="mw-redirect" title="Intangible Cultural Heritage">Intangible Cultural Heritage</a> list. </p>
      <p>Being a mountainous country, Iran is a venue for <a href="/wiki/Skiing" title="Skiing">skiing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Snowboarding" title="Snowboarding">snowboarding</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hiking" title="Hiking">hiking</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rock_climbing" title="Rock climbing">rock climbing</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-517" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-517">[515]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Mountaineering" title="Mountaineering">mountain climbing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-518" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-518">[516]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-519" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-519">[517]</a></sup> It is home to several ski resorts, the most famous being <a href="/wiki/Tochal_Complex" title="Tochal Complex">Tochal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dizin" title="Dizin">Dizin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Shemshak_(ski_resort)" title="Shemshak (ski resort)">Shemshak</a>, all within one to three hours traveling from the capital city Tehran.<sup id="cite_ref-Snowseasoncentral.com_November_29_2015c_520-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Snowseasoncentral.com_November_29_2015c-520">[518]</a></sup> The resort of Tochal, located in the <a href="/wiki/Alborz" title="Alborz">Alborz</a> mountain rage, is the world's fifth-highest ski resort (3,730&nbsp;m or 12,238&nbsp;ft at its highest station). </p>
      <p>Iran's <a href="/wiki/National_Olympic_Committee_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="National Olympic Committee of the Islamic Republic of Iran">National Olympic Committee</a> was founded in 1947. Wrestlers and <a href="/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting" title="Olympic weightlifting">weightlifters</a> have achieved the country's highest <a href="/wiki/Iran_at_the_Olympics" title="Iran at the Olympics">records at the Olympics</a>. In September 1974, Iran became the first country in West Asia to host the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Games" title="Asian Games">Asian Games</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Azadi_Sport_Complex" title="Azadi Sport Complex">Azadi Sport Complex</a>, which is the largest sport complex in Iran, was originally built for this occasion. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Persepolis_fans_at_Azadi_Stadium_1396.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Persepolis_fans_at_Azadi_Stadium_1396.jpg/220px-Persepolis_fans_at_Azadi_Stadium_1396.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="136" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Persepolis_fans_at_Azadi_Stadium_1396.jpg/330px-Persepolis_fans_at_Azadi_Stadium_1396.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Persepolis_fans_at_Azadi_Stadium_1396.jpg/440px-Persepolis_fans_at_Azadi_Stadium_1396.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="495"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Persepolis_fans_at_Azadi_Stadium_1396.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Azadi_Stadium" title="Azadi Stadium">Azadi Stadium</a> in <a href="/wiki/Tehran" title="Tehran">Tehran</a> is <a href="/wiki/List_of_association_football_stadiums_by_capacity" title="List of association football stadiums by capacity">West Asia's largest football stadium</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Football_in_Iran" title="Football in Iran">Football</a> has been regarded as the most popular sport in Iran, with the <a href="/wiki/Iran_national_football_team" title="Iran national football team">men's national team</a> having won the <a href="/wiki/AFC_Asian_Cup" title="AFC Asian Cup">Asian Cup</a> on three occasions. The men's national team has maintained its position as Asia's best team, ranking 1st in Asia and 33rd in the world according to the <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Rankings" title="FIFA World Rankings">FIFA World Rankings</a> (as of May 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iran&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>).<sup id="cite_ref-521" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-521">[519]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Volleyball is the second most popular sport in Iran.<sup id="cite_ref-522" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-522">[520]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-523" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-523">[521]</a></sup> Having won the 2011 and 2013 <a href="/wiki/Asian_Men%27s_Volleyball_Championship" title="Asian Men's Volleyball Championship">Asian Men's Volleyball Championships</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Iran_men%27s_national_volleyball_team" title="Iran men's national volleyball team">men's national team</a> is currently the strongest team in Asia, and ranks eighth in the <a href="/wiki/FIVB_World_Rankings" class="mw-redirect" title="FIVB World Rankings">FIVB World Rankings</a> (as of July&nbsp;2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iran&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>). </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">Basketball</a> is also popular,<sup id="cite_ref-524" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-524">[522]</a></sup> with the <a href="/wiki/Iran_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Iran national basketball team">men's national team</a> having won three <a href="/wiki/FIBA_Asia_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="FIBA Asia Championship">Asian Championships</a> since 2007. </p>
      <p>In 2016, Iran made global headlines for international female champions boycotting tournaments in Iran in chess (U.S. Woman Grandmaster <a href="/wiki/Naz%C3%AD_Paikidze" title="Nazí Paikidze">Nazí Paikidze</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-525" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-525">[523]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-526" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-526">[524]</a></sup> and in shooting (Indian world champion <a href="/wiki/Heena_Sidhu" title="Heena Sidhu">Heena Sidhu</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-527" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-527">[525]</a></sup> as they refused to enter a country where they would be forced to wear a <a href="/wiki/Hijab" title="Hijab">hijab</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Iran" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Iran">Media of Iran</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Iran is one of the countries with the worst <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a> situation, ranking 164th out of 180 countries on the <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">Press Freedom Index</a> (as of 2018).<sup id="cite_ref-528" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-528">[526]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture_and_Islamic_Guidance" title="Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance">Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance</a> is Iran's main government department responsible for the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_policy" title="Cultural policy">cultural policy</a>, including activities regarding communications and information.<sup id="cite_ref-529" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-529">[527]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Iran's first newspapers were published during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Naser_al-Din_Shah_Qajar" title="Naser al-Din Shah Qajar">Naser al-Din Shah</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Qajar_dynasty" title="Qajar dynasty">Qajar dynasty</a> in the mid-19th century.<sup id="cite_ref-530" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-530">[528]</a></sup> Most of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Iran" title="List of newspapers in Iran">newspapers published in Iran</a> are in Persian, the country's official language. The country's most widely circulated periodicals are based in Tehran, among which are <i><a href="/wiki/Etemad" title="Etemad">Etemad</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Ettela%27at" title="Ettela'at">Ettela'at</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Kayhan" title="Kayhan">Kayhan</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Hamshahri" title="Hamshahri">Hamshahri</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Resalat_(newspaper)" title="Resalat (newspaper)">Resalat</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Shargh" title="Shargh">Shargh</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-BYI_321-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BYI-321">[319]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Tehran_Times" title="Tehran Times">Tehran Times</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Iran_(newspaper)" title="Iran (newspaper)">Iran Daily</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Financial_Tribune" title="Financial Tribune">Financial Tribune</a></i> are among English-language newspapers based in Iran. </p>
      <p>Television was introduced in Iran in 1958.<sup id="cite_ref-FisherAvery1991p810_531-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FisherAvery1991p810-531">[529]</a></sup> Although the <a href="/wiki/1974_Asian_Games" title="1974 Asian Games">1974 Asian Games</a> were broadcast in color, full color programming began in 1978.<sup id="cite_ref-FisherAvery1991p810_531-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FisherAvery1991p810-531">[529]</a></sup> Since the 1979 Revolution, Iran's largest media corporation is the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Republic_of_Iran_Broadcasting" title="Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting">Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting</a> (IRIB).<sup id="cite_ref-BYI_321-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BYI-321">[319]</a></sup> Despite the restrictions on non-domestic television, about 65% of the residents of the capital city and about 30 to 40% of the residents outside the capital city access worldwide television channels through <a href="/wiki/Satellite_dish" title="Satellite dish">satellite dishes</a>, although observers state that the figures are likely to be higher.<sup id="cite_ref-532" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-532">[530]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-533" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-533">[531]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Iran received access to the Internet in 1993. According to Internet World Stats, as of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iran&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, around 69.1% of the population of Iran are Internet users.<sup id="cite_ref-IWStats_534-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IWStats-534">[532]</a></sup> Iran ranks 17th among <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_Internet_users" title="List of countries by number of Internet users">countries by number of Internet users</a>. According to the statistics provided by the web information company of <a href="/wiki/Alexa_Internet" title="Alexa Internet">Alexa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google_Search" title="Google Search">Google Search</a> is Iran's most widely used search engine and <a href="/wiki/Instagram" title="Instagram">Instagram</a> is the most popular online <a href="/wiki/Social_networking_service" title="Social networking service">social networking service</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Alexa_Internet_535-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Alexa_Internet-535">[533]</a></sup> Direct access to many worldwide mainstream websites has been blocked in Iran, including <a href="/wiki/Facebook" title="Facebook">Facebook</a>, which has been blocked since 2009 due to the organization of anti-governmental protests on the website.<sup id="cite_ref-536" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-536">[534]</a></sup> However, as of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iran&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Facebook has around 40 million subscribers based in Iran (48.8% of the population) who use <a href="/wiki/Virtual_private_network" title="Virtual private network">virtual private networks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Proxy_server" title="Proxy server">proxy servers</a> to access the website.<sup id="cite_ref-IWStats_534-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IWStats-534">[532]</a></sup> Some of the officials themselves have verified accounts on the social networking websites that are blocked by the authorities, including Facebook and <a href="/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">Twitter</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-537" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-537">[535]</a></sup> About 90% of Iran's <a href="/wiki/E-commerce" title="E-commerce">e-commerce</a> takes place on the Iranian online store of Digikala, which has around 750,000 visitors per day and more than 2.3 million subscribers and is the most visited online store in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-538" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-538">[536]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Alexa_Internet_535-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Alexa_Internet-535">[533]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fashion_and_clothing">Fashion and clothing</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Fashion_in_Iran" title="Fashion in Iran">Fashion in Iran</a>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Fashion_in_Iran" title="Fashion in Iran">Fashion in Iran</a> is divided into several historical periods. The exact date of the emergence of <a href="/wiki/Weaving" title="Weaving">weaving</a> in Iran is not yet known, but it is likely to coincide with the emergence of <a href="/wiki/Civilization" title="Civilization">civilization</a>. Clothing in Iran is mentioned in <a href="/wiki/Persian_mythology" title="Persian mythology">Persian mythology</a>. <a href="/wiki/Ferdowsi" title="Ferdowsi">Ferdowsi</a> and many historians have considered <a href="/wiki/Keyumars" title="Keyumars">Keyumars</a> to be the inventor of the use of <a href="/wiki/Animal_skin" class="mw-redirect" title="Animal skin">animals' skin</a> and hair as clothing. Some historians have also mentioned <a href="/wiki/Hushang" title="Hushang">Hushang</a> as the first inventor of the use of living skins as clothing.<sup id="cite_ref-:02_539-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-539">[537]</a></sup> Ferdowsi considers <a href="/wiki/Tahmuras" title="Tahmuras">Tahmuras</a> to be a kind of <a href="/wiki/Textile" title="Textile">textile</a> initiator in Iran. There are historical discoveries in northern Iran from about 6,000 BC that refer to <a href="/wiki/Wool" title="Wool">wool</a> weaving at the time. Other discoveries in central Iran dating back to 4200 BC have shown that the animals' skin has not been the only clothing worn on the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Plateau" title="Iranian Plateau">Iranian Plateau</a> since those years. The clothing of ancient Iran took an advanced form, and the fabric and color of clothing became very important at that time. Depending on the social status, eminence, climate of the region and the season, <a href="/wiki/Persian_clothing" title="Persian clothing">Persian clothing</a> during the Achaemenian period took various forms. The philosophy used in this clothing, in addition to being functional, also had an aesthetic role.<sup id="cite_ref-:02_539-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-539">[537]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Beauty_pageant" title="Beauty pageant">Beauty pageant</a> festivals inside Iran were not held after the <a href="/wiki/1979_revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="1979 revolution">1979 revolution</a>, and the last selection ceremony of the "beauty queen of Iran" was held in 1978 in this country. Since then, a high number of Iranian girls participated in the Beauty pageant and Miss Universe outside of Iran. <a href="/wiki/Sahar_Biniaz" title="Sahar Biniaz">Sahar Biniaz</a> (<a href="/wiki/Miss_Universe_Canada_2012" title="Miss Universe Canada 2012">Miss Universe Canada 2012</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Shermine_Shahrivar" title="Shermine Shahrivar">Shermineh Shahrivar</a> (<a href="/wiki/Miss_Germany" title="Miss Germany">Miss Germany</a> and <a href="/wiki/Miss_Europe" title="Miss Europe">Miss Europe</a>) are examples of Iranian models outside Iran.<sup id="cite_ref-540" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-540">[538]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-541" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-541">[539]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Girls_of_Enghelab_Street" class="mw-redirect" title="Girls of Enghelab Street">Girls of Enghelab Street</a> was a series of protests in 2017–2019 against a <a href="/wiki/Hijab_by_country#Iran" title="Hijab by country">compulsory hijab</a> in Iran.<sup id="cite_ref-542" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-542">[540]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/List_of_Iran-related_topics" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Iran-related topics">List of Iran-related topics</a></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Iran" title="Outline of Iran">Outline of Iran</a></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Name_of_Iran" title="Name of Iran">Name of Iran</a></li>
      </ul> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style>
      <div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Including the <a href="/wiki/Nakhchivan_Autonomous_Republic" title="Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic">Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic</a></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-38"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-38">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In the Avesta, the <i>airiia-</i> are members of the ethnic group of the Avesta-reciters themselves, in contradistinction to the <i>anairiia-</i> (the "<a href="/wiki/Aniran" class="mw-redirect" title="Aniran">non-Arya</a>"). The word also appears four times in Old Persian: One is in the <a href="/wiki/Behistun_inscription" class="mw-redirect" title="Behistun inscription">Behistun inscription</a>, where <i>ariya-</i> is the name of a language (DB 4.89). The other three instances occur in <a href="/wiki/Darius_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Darius I">Darius I</a>'s inscription at <a href="/wiki/Naqsh-e_Rustam" class="mw-redirect" title="Naqsh-e Rustam">Naqsh-e Rustam</a> (DNa 14–15), in Darius I's inscription at Susa (DSe 13–14), and in the inscription of <a href="/wiki/Xerxes_I" title="Xerxes I">Xerxes I</a> at <a href="/wiki/Persepolis" title="Persepolis">Persepolis</a> (XPh 12–13). In these, the two Achaemenid dynasties describe themselves as <i>pārsa pārsahyā puça ariya ariyaciça</i> "a Persian, son of a Persian, an Ariya, of Ariya origin."—The phrase with <i>ciça</i> ("origin, descendance") assures that <i>ariya</i> is an ethnic name wider in meaning than <i>pārsa</i> and not a simple adjectival epithet.<sup id="cite_ref-Bailey_Arya_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bailey_Arya-37">[36]</a></sup></span> </li> 
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div>

         <li id="cite_note-CIA-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_3-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_3-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_3-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_3-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_3-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_3-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_3-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_3-7"><sup><i><b>h</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/iran/">"Iran"</a>. <i>The World Factbook</i>.          <li id="cite_note-Sarkhosh-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Sarkhosh_4-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Sarkhosh_4-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSarkhosh_Curtis,_VestaStewart,_Sarah2005" class="citation cs2">Sarkhosh Curtis, Vesta; Stewart, Sarah (2005), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=a0IF9IdkdYEC"><i>Birth of the Persian Empire: The Idea of Iran</i></a>, London: I.B. Tauris, p.&nbsp;108, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-84511-062-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-84511-062-8"><bdi>978-1-84511-062-8</bdi></a>, <q>Similarly the collapse of Sassanian Eranshahr in AD 650 did not end Iranians' national idea. The name 'Iran' disappeared from official records of the Saffarids, Samanids, Buyids, Saljuqs and their successor. But one unofficially used the name Iran, Eranshahr, and similar national designations, particularly Mamalek-e Iran or 'Iranian lands', which exactly translated the old Avestan term Ariyanam Daihunam. On the other hand, when the Safavids (not Reza Shah, as is popularly assumed) revived a national state officially known as Iran, bureaucratic usage in the Ottoman empire and even Iran itself could still refer to it by other descriptive and traditional appellations.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Birth+of+the+Persian+Empire%3A+The+Idea+of+Iran&amp;rft.place=London&amp;rft.pages=108&amp;rft.pub=I.B.+Tauris&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-84511-062-8&amp;rft.au=Sarkhosh+Curtis%2C+Vesta&amp;rft.au=Stewart%2C+Sarah&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Da0IF9IdkdYEC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-Data.worldbank.org-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Data.worldbank.org_9-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150209003326/https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/si.pov.gini">"GINI index (World Bank estimate)"</a>. <i>Data.worldbank.org</i>.          <li id="cite_note-UNHDR-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-UNHDR_10-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation book cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://hdr.undp.org/sites/default/files/hdr2020.pdf"><i>Human Development Report 2020 The Next Frontier: Human Development and the Anthropocene</i></a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>.            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080410011625/http://fa.wikisource.org/wiki/%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%88%D9%86_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%A7%D8%B3%DB%8C_%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%85%DB%8C_%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86"><bdi lang="fa">قانون اساسی جمهوری اسلامی ایران</bdi></a> (in Persian).          <li id="cite_note-MacKenzie-34"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-MacKenzie_34-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-MacKenzie_34-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMacKenzie1998" class="citation encyclopaedia cs1">MacKenzie, David Niel (1998). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170313095654/http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/eran-eransah">"Ērān, Ērānšahr"</a>. <i>Encyclopedia Iranica</i>. <b>8</b>. Costa Mesa: Mazda. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/eran-eransah">the original</a> on 13 March 2017.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=%C4%92r%C4%81n%2C+%C4%92r%C4%81n%C5%A1ahr&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+Iranica&amp;rft.place=Costa+Mesa&amp;rft.pub=Mazda&amp;rft.date=1998&amp;rft.aulast=MacKenzie&amp;rft.aufirst=David+Niel&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.iranicaonline.org%2Farticles%2Feran-eransah&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Schmitt_Aryans1-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Schmitt_Aryans1_35-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Schmitt_Aryans1_35-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSchmitt1987" class="citation cs2">Schmitt, Rüdiger (1987), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/aryans">"Aryans"</a>, <i>Encyclopedia Iranica</i>, vol. 2, New York: Routledge &amp; Kegan Paul, pp.&nbsp;684–687</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Aryans&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+Iranica&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.series=vol.+2&amp;rft.pages=684-687&amp;rft.pub=Routledge+%26+Kegan+Paul&amp;rft.date=1987&amp;rft.aulast=Schmitt&amp;rft.aufirst=R%C3%BCdiger&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.iranicaonline.org%2Farticles%2Faryans&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-36"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-36">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Laroche. 1957. Proto-Iranian <i>*arya-</i> descends from Proto-Indo-European (PIE) <i><span title="Proto-Indo-European language" class="Unicode" lang="ine" style="white-space:nowrap;">*ar-yo-</span></i>, a <i>yo-</i>adjective to a root <span title="Proto-Indo-European language" class="Unicode" lang="ine" style="white-space:nowrap;">*ar</span> "to assemble skillfully", present in Greek <i>harma</i> "chariot", Greek <i>aristos</i>, (as in "<a href="/wiki/Aristocracy" title="Aristocracy">aristocracy</a>"), Latin <i>ars</i> "art", etc.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Bailey_Arya-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Bailey_Arya_37-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Bailey_Arya_37-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBailey1987" class="citation encyclopaedia cs1"><a href="/wiki/Harold_Walter_Bailey" title="Harold Walter Bailey">Bailey, Harold Walter</a> (1987). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160303194904/http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/arya-an-ethnic-epithet">"Arya"</a>. <i>Encyclopedia Iranica</i>. <b>2</b>. New York: Routledge &amp; Kegan Paul. pp.&nbsp;681–683. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/arya-an-ethnic-epithet">the original</a> on 3 March 2016.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Arya&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+Iranica&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pages=681-683&amp;rft.pub=Routledge+%26+Kegan+Paul&amp;rft.date=1987&amp;rft.aulast=Bailey&amp;rft.aufirst=Harold+Walter&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.iranicaonline.org%2Farticles%2Farya-an-ethnic-epithet&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Iranica-39"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Iranica_39-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFShapour_Shahbazi" class="citation web cs1">Shapour Shahbazi, Alireza. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/iraj">"IRAJ"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Iranica" class="mw-redirect" title="Iranica">Iranica</a> website<span class="reference-accessdate">.          <li id="cite_note-40"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-40">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.britannica.com/place/Persia">Persia</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica" title="Encyclopædia Britannica">Encyclopædia Britannica</a></i>, "The term Persia was used for centuries<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>... [because] use of the name was gradually extended by the ancient Greeks and other peoples to apply to the whole Iranian plateau."</span> </li>

           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130523020103/http://www.art-arena.com/history.html">"Persia or Iran, a brief history"</a>.
