         <li id="cite_note-46"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-46">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation audio-visual cs1"><a href="/wiki/Richard_N._Frye" title="Richard N. Frye">Richard N. Frye</a> (20 October 2007). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160423185051/http://azadegan.info/files/Dr.Frye-discusses-greater-Iran-on-CNN.mp4"><i>interview by Asieh Namdar</i></a>. CNN. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://azadegan.info/files/Dr.Frye-discusses-greater-Iran-on-CNN.mp4">the original</a> on 23 April 2016. <q>I spent all my life working in Iran, and as you know I don't mean Iran of today, I mean Greater Iran, the Iran which in the past, extended all the way from China to borders of Hungary and from other Mongolia to Mesopotamia</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=interview+by+Asieh+Namdar&amp;rft.pub=CNN&amp;rft.date=2007-10-20&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fazadegan.info%2Ffiles%2FDr.Frye-discusses-greater-Iran-on-CNN.mp4&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-47"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-47">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFChristoph_Marcinkowski2010" class="citation book cs1">Christoph Marcinkowski (2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=F9khRsDDuX8C&amp;pg=PA83"><i>Shi'ite Identities: Community and Culture in Changing Social Contexts</i></a>. LIT Verlag Münster. p.&nbsp;83. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-3-643-80049-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-3-643-80049-7"><bdi>978-3-643-80049-7</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">21 June</span> 2013</span>. <q>The 'historical lands of Iran' – 'Greater Iran' – were always known in the Persian language as Irānshahr or Irānzamīn.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Shi%27ite+Identities%3A+Community+and+Culture+in+Changing+Social+Contexts&amp;rft.pages=83&amp;rft.pub=LIT+Verlag+M%C3%BCnster&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-3-643-80049-7&amp;rft.au=Christoph+Marcinkowski&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DF9khRsDDuX8C%26pg%3DPA83&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-48"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-48">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFFrye1962" class="citation journal cs1">Frye, Richard Nelson (October 1962). "Reitzenstein and Qumrân Revisited by an Iranian". <i>The Harvard Theological Review</i>. <b>55</b> (4): 261–268. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1017%2FS0017816000007926">10.1017/S0017816000007926</a>. <a href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/1508723">1508723</a>. <q>I use the term Iran in an historical context [...] Persia would be used for the modern state, more or less equivalent to "western Iran". I use the term "Greater Iran" to mean what I suspect most Classicists and ancient historians really mean by their use of Persia – that which was within the political boundaries of States ruled by Iranians.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Harvard+Theological+Review&amp;rft.atitle=Reitzenstein+and+Qumr%C3%A2n+Revisited+by+an+Iranian&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.pages=261-268&amp;rft.date=1962-10&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2FS0017816000007926&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F1508723%23id-name%3DJSTOR&amp;rft.aulast=Frye&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard+Nelson&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-49"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-49">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFRichard_Frye2012" class="citation book cs1">Richard Frye (2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=9QOfAvCP1jkC&amp;pg=PA13"><i>Persia (RLE Iran A)</i></a>. Routledge. p.&nbsp;13. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-136-84154-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-136-84154-5"><bdi>978-1-136-84154-5</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">21 June</span> 2013</span>. <q>This 'greater Iran' included and still includes part of the Caucasus Mountains, Central Asia, Afghanistan, and Iraq; for Kurds, Baluchis, Afghans, Tajiks, Ossetes, and other smaller groups are Iranians</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Persia+%28RLE+Iran+A%29&amp;rft.pages=13&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-136-84154-5&amp;rft.au=Richard+Frye&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D9QOfAvCP1jkC%26pg%3DPA13&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-50"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-50">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Farrokh, Kaveh. Shadows in the Desert: Ancient Persia at War. 
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-84603-108-7" title="Special:BookSources/1-84603-108-7">1-84603-108-7</a></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-64"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-64">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFK._Kris_Hirst" class="citation web cs1">K. Kris Hirst. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131106002737/http://archaeology.about.com/od/cterms/g/choghamish.htm">"Chogha Mish (Iran)"</a>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://archaeology.about.com/od/cterms/g/choghamish.htm">the original</a> on 6 November 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 December</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Chogha+Mish+%28Iran%29&amp;rft.au=K.+Kris+Hirst&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Farchaeology.about.com%2Fod%2Fcterms%2Fg%2Fchoghamish.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-65"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-65">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFCollon1995" class="citation book cs1">Collon, Dominique (1995). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=RTGc9YH-C38C"><i>Ancient Near Eastern Art</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-75"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-75">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110514024224/http://www.iranchamber.com/history/median/median.php">"Median Empire"</a>.          <li id="cite_note-Sagona2006-76"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Sagona2006_76-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFA._G._Sagona2006" class="citation book cs1">A. G. Sagona (2006). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=bW06PE0GRXEC&amp;pg=PA91"><i>The Heritage of Eastern Turkey: From Earliest Settlements to Islam</i></a>.          <li id="cite_note-77"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-77">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150701005402/http://www.allaboutturkey.com/urartu.htm">"Urartu civilization"</a>. <i>allaboutturkey.com</i>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.allaboutturkey.com/urartu.htm">the original</a> on 1 July 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">26 August</span> 2015</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=allaboutturkey.com&amp;rft.atitle=Urartu+civilization&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.allaboutturkey.com%2Furartu.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-1996,_p._47-78"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1996,_p._47_78-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFEhsan_Yarshater1996" class="citation book cs1">Ehsan Yarshater (1996). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=WBAZAQAAIAAJ&amp;q=%28Meyer+p.85%29"><i>Encyclopaedia Iranica</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Routledge" title="Routledge">Routledge &amp; Kegan Paul</a>. p.&nbsp;47. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-56859-028-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-56859-028-8"><bdi>978-1-56859-028-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopaedia+Iranica&amp;rft.pages=47&amp;rft.pub=Routledge+%26+Kegan+Paul&amp;rft.date=1996&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-56859-028-8&amp;rft.au=Ehsan+Yarshater&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DWBAZAQAAIAAJ%26q%3D%2528Meyer%2Bp.85%2529&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Cook-79"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Cook_79-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">While estimates for the Achaemenid Empire range from 10–80+ million, most prefer 50 million. Prevas (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=1S-Q-6jDZ7AC&amp;pg=PA14">2009, p. 14</a>) estimates 10 million. Strauss (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=nQFtMcD5dOsC&amp;pg=PA37">2004, p. 37</a>) estimates about 20 million. Ward (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=8eUTLaaVOOQC&amp;pg=PA16">2009, p. 16</a>) estimates at 20 million. Scheidel (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=6vnkts2rOJUC&amp;pg=PA99">2009, p. 99</a>) estimates 35 million. Daniel (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=AzqbYf9Q_2UC&amp;pg=PA41">2001, p. 41</a>) estimates at 50 million. Meyer and Andreades (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Uwn9d01zMvAC&amp;pg=PA58">2004, p. 58</a>) estimates to 50 million. Jones (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=75ueY2rqTYMC&amp;pg=PA8">2004, p. 8</a>) estimates over 50 million. Richard (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=toJI-Z_WAC0C&amp;pg=PA34">2008, p. 34</a>) estimates nearly 70 million. Hanson (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/carnageculturela00hans">2001, p. 32</a>) estimates almost 75 million. Cowley (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=l6JmAAAAMAAJ">1999 and 2001, p. 17</a>) estimates possibly 80 million.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-80"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-80">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/largest-empire-by-percentage-of-world-population/">"Largest empire by percentage of world population"</a>. Guinness World Records<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">11 March</span> 2015</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Largest+empire+by+percentage+of+world+population&amp;rft.pub=Guinness+World+Records&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.guinnessworldrecords.com%2Fworld-records%2Flargest-empire-by-percentage-of-world-population%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-81"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-81">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation encyclopaedia cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Cyrus-the-Great">"Cyrus the Great"</a>. <i>Encyclopedia Britannica</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 November</span> 2018</span>. <q>In the Bible (e.g., Ezra 1:1–4), Cyrus is famous for freeing the Jewish captives in Babylonia and allowing them to return to their homeland.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Cyrus+the+Great&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+Britannica&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2Fbiography%2FCyrus-the-Great&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-82"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-82">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSchmitt" class="citation encyclopaedia cs1">Schmitt, Rüdiger. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20151203002422/http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/achaemenid-dynasty">"Achaemenid dynasty"</a>. <i>Encyclopaedia Iranica</i>. vol. 3.          <li id="cite_note-schmitt-EI-i-83"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-schmitt-EI-i_83-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#refachaemenids-EI">Schmitt</a> Achaemenid dynasty (i. The clan and dynasty)</span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-Hashemi2008-98"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Hashemi2008_98-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-113"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-113">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBosworth" class="citation web cs1">Bosworth, C.          <li id="cite_note-137"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-137">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Griboedov not only extended protection to those Caucasian captives who sought to go home but actively promoted the return of even those who did not volunteer.          <li id="cite_note-142"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-142">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFGingeras2016" class="citation book cs1">Gingeras, Ryan (2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=sGyMCwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA166"><i>Fall of the Sultanate: The Great War and the End of the Ottoman Empire 1908–1922</i></a>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 June</span> 2016</span>. <q>By January, Ottoman regulars and cavalry detachments associated with the old Hamidiye had seized the towns of Urmia, Khoy, and Salmas.          <li id="cite_note-Kevorkian2011-143"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Kevorkian2011_143-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFKevorkian2011" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Raymond_K%C3%A9vorkian" title="Raymond Kévorkian">Kevorkian, Raymond</a> (2011). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=mZ33AgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA710"><i>The Armenian Genocide: A Complete History</i></a>. I.B. Tauris. p.&nbsp;710. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-85773-020-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-85773-020-6"><bdi>978-0-85773-020-6</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 June</span> 2016</span>. <q>'In retaliation, we killed the Armenians of Khoy, and I gave the order to massacre the Armenians of Maku.'<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>... Without distorting the facts, one can affirm that the centuries-old Armenian presence in the regions of Urmia, Salmast, Qaradagh, and Maku had been dealt a blow from which it would never recover.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Armenian+Genocide%3A+A+Complete+History&amp;rft.pages=710&amp;rft.pub=I.B.+Tauris&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-85773-020-6&amp;rft.aulast=Kevorkian&amp;rft.aufirst=Raymond&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DmZ33AgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA710&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-150"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-150">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-169"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-169">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAbrahamian2008" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Ervand_Abrahamian" title="Ervand Abrahamian">Abrahamian, Ervand</a> (2008). <span class="cs1-lock-limited" title="Free access subject to limited trial, subscription normally required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/historymodernira00abra"><i>A History of Modern Iran</i></a></span>.          <li id="cite_note-Borrini-FeyerabendFarvar2013-203"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Borrini-FeyerabendFarvar2013_203-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFGrazia_Borrini-FeyerabendM._Taghi_FarvarYves_RenardMichel_P_Pimbert2013" class="citation book cs1">Grazia Borrini-Feyerabend; M. Taghi Farvar; Yves Renard; Michel P Pimbert; Ashish Kothari (2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=MfS3AAAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA120"><i>Sharing Power: A Global Guide to Collaborative Management of Natural Resources</i></a>. Routledge. p.&nbsp;120. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-136-55742-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-136-55742-2"><bdi>978-1-136-55742-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Sharing+Power%3A+A+Global+Guide+to+Collaborative+Management+of+Natural+Resources&amp;rft.pages=120&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-136-55742-2&amp;rft.au=Grazia+Borrini-Feyerabend&amp;rft.au=M.+Taghi+Farvar&amp;rft.au=Yves+Renard&amp;rft.au=Michel+P+Pimbert&amp;rft.au=Ashish+Kothari&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DMfS3AAAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA120&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-iucn-204"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-iucn_204-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFKhorozyan,_I.2008" class="citation journal cs1">Khorozyan, I.          <li id="cite_note-rubin80-272"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-rubin80_272-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-288"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-288">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-289"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-289">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.hrw.org/news/2018/02/24/iran-stop-prosecuting-women-over-dress-code">"Iran: Stop Prosecuting Women Over Dress Code"</a>. Human Rights Watch. 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 March</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Iran%3A+Stop+Prosecuting+Women+Over+Dress+Code&amp;rft.pub=Human+Rights+Watch&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.hrw.org%2Fnews%2F2018%2F02%2F24%2Firan-stop-prosecuting-women-over-dress-code&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-290"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-290">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.hrw.org/news/2018/02/07/iran-three-child-offenders-executed">"Iran: Three Child Offenders Executed"</a>. Human Rights Watch. 2018.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Iran%3A+Three+Child+Offenders+Executed&amp;rft.pub=Human+Rights+Watch&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.hrw.org%2Fnews%2F2018%2F02%2F07%2Firan-three-child-offenders-executed&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-291"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-291">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFFreedom_House2017" class="citation web cs1">Freedom House (2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2017/iran">"Iran"</a>. <i>Freedom in the World 2017</i>. Freedom House<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">25 May</span> 2017</span>. <q>The Islamic Republic of Iran holds elections regularly, but they fall short of democratic standards due to the role of the hard-line Guardian Council, which disqualifies all candidates deemed insufficiently loyal to the clerical establishment. Ultimate power rests in the hands of the country's <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Leader_of_Iran" title="Supreme Leader of Iran">supreme leader</a>, Ayatollah <a href="/wiki/Ali_Khamenei" title="Ali Khamenei">Ali Khamenei</a>, and the unelected institutions under his control. Human rights abuses continued unabated in 2016, with the authorities carrying out Iran's largest mass execution in years and launching a renewed crackdown on women's rights activists. The regime maintained restrictions on freedom of expression, both offline and online, and made further arrests of journalists, bloggers, labor union activists, and dual nationals visiting the country, with some facing heavy prison sentences. Hard-liners in control of powerful institutions, including the judiciary and the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC), were behind many of the year's abuses. There were no indications that President Hassan Rouhani, a self-proclaimed moderate seeking reelection in 2017, was willing or able to push back against repressive forces and deliver the greater social freedoms he had promised. Opposition leaders Mir Hossein Mousavi, his wife Zahra Rahnavard, and reformist cleric Mehdi Karroubi remained under house arrest for a sixth year without being formally charged or put on trial. As in 2015, the media were barred from quoting or reporting on former president Mohammad Khatami, another important reformist figure.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Freedom+in+the+World+2017&amp;rft.atitle=Iran&amp;rft.date=2017&amp;rft.au=Freedom+House&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Ffreedomhouse.org%2Freport%2Ffreedom-world%2F2017%2Firan&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-292"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-292">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-382"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-382">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFChardin1997" class="citation journal cs1"><a href="/wiki/Jean_Chardin" title="Jean Chardin">Chardin, Sir John</a> (June 1997). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://iranian.com/Travelers/June97/Chardin/index.shtml">"Persians: Kind, hospitable, tolerant flattering cheats?"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Iranian.com" title="Iranian.com">The Iranian</a></i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/19970620173929/http://www.iranian.com/Travelers/June97/Chardin/index.shtml">Archived</a> from the original on 20 June 1997<span class="reference-accessdate">.            <ul>
            <li>
             <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFChardin1988" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Jean_Chardin" title="Jean Chardin">Chardin, Sir John</a> (1988). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=5jPL0A31H5MC&amp;pg=PA183">"Book 2, Chapter XI: Of the Temper, Manners, and Customs of the Persians: A XVII th.          <li id="cite_note-383"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-383">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">J.          <li id="cite_note-384"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-384">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-New_America_Foundation-385"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-New_America_Foundation_385-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130723044939/http://www.terrorfreetomorrow.org/upimagestft/TFT%20Iran%20Survey%20Report%200609.pdf">"Results a new nationwide public opinion survey of Iran"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <a href="/wiki/New_America_Foundation" class="mw-redirect" title="New America Foundation">New America Foundation</a>. 12 June 2009.          <li id="cite_note-Minority_Rights-386"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Minority_Rights_386-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.minorityrights.org/?lid=5096">"Azeris"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Minority_Rights_Group_International" title="Minority Rights Group International">Minority Rights Group International</a>. 2009<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">16 October</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=Azeris&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.minorityrights.org%2F%3Flid%3D5096&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-387"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-387">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"> 
           <ul>
            <li>Shaffer, Brenda (2003). Borders and Brethren: Iran and the Challenge of Azerbaijani Identity. MIT Press. pp. 221–225. 
             <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-262-19477-5" title="Special:BookSources/0-262-19477-5">0-262-19477-5</a> "There is considerable lack of consensus regarding the number of Azerbaijanis in Iran<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>... Most conventional estimates of the Azerbaijani population range between one-fifth to one-third of the general population of Iran, the majority claiming one-fourth." – "Azerbaijani student groups in Iran claim that there are 27 million Azerbaijanis residing in Iran."</li> 
            <li>Minahan, James (2002). Encyclopedia of the Stateless Nations: S-Z. Greenwood Publishing Group. p. 1765. 
             <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-313-32384-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-313-32384-3">978-0-313-32384-3</a> "Approximately (2002e) 18,500,000 Southern Azeris in Iran, concentrated in the northwestern provinces of East and West Azerbaijan. It is difficult to determine the exact number of Southern Azeris in Iran, as official statistics are not published detailing Iran's ethnic structure. Estimates of the Southern Azeri population range from as low as 12 million up to 40% of the population of Iran – that is, nearly 27 million<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>..."</li>
           </ul> </span></li> 
         <li id="cite_note-388"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-388">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Rasmus Christian Elling, Minorities in Iran: Nationalism and Ethnicity after Khomeini, Palgrave Macmillan, 2013. Excerpt: "The number of Azeris in Iran is heavily disputed. In 2005, Amanolahi estimated all Turkic-speaking communities in Iran to number no more than 9<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>million. CIA and Library of congress estimates range from 16 percent to 24 percent—that is, 12–18 million people if we employ the latest total figure for Iran's population (77.8 million). Azeri ethnicsts, on the other hand, argue that overall number is much higher, even as much as 50 percent or more of the total population. Such inflated estimates may have influenced some Western scholars who suggest that up to 30 percent (that is, some 23 million today) Iranians are Azeris." <a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=rWEbrv5oD8AC">[8]</a></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-Criticism-389"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Criticism_389-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Ali Gheissari. <i>Contemporary Iran: Economy, Society – Politics: Economy, Society, Politics</i>. p. 300. "Azeri ethnonationalist activist, however, claim that number to be 24 million, hence as high as 35 percent of the Iranian population." Oxford University Press. 2 April 2009.</span> </li>

           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFMalandra1973" class="citation journal cs1">Malandra, W.W. (1973). "A Glossary of Terms for Weapons and Armor in Old Iranian". <i>Indo-Iranian Journal</i>.          <li id="cite_note-510"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-510">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBelton,_Howard2015" class="citation book cs1">Belton, Howard (13 March 2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=qu97BwAAQBAJ">"Ice cream"</a>. <i>A History of The World in Five Menus</i>.       <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Bibliography">Bibliography</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011217839">.mw-parser-output .refbegin{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul{margin-left:0}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul>li{margin-left:0;padding-left:3.2em;text-indent:-3.2em}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents ul,.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents ul li{list-style:none}@media(max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul>li{padding-left:1.6em;text-indent:-1.6em}}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-100{font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns ul{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}</style>
      <div class="refbegin" style=""> 
       <ul>
        <li>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAxworthy2008" class="citation book cs1">Axworthy, Michael (2008). <i>A History of Iran: Empire of the Mind</i>.         <li>

                            <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:9.0em;font-weight:normal;font-size:85%;">550 BC – <a href="/wiki/Common_Era" title="Common Era">CE</a> 224</th>

                               <li><a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid <span class="nowrap">Empire <span style="font-size:85%;">(330 – 63 BC)</span></span></a></li> 
                               <li><a href="/wiki/Frataraka" title="Frataraka">Frataraka</a></li> 
                               <li><a href="/wiki/Kings_of_Persis" title="Kings of Persis">Kings of Persis</a></li> 
                               <li><a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Pontus" title="Kingdom of Pontus">Kingdom of <span class="nowrap">Pontus <span style="font-size:85%;">(281 BC – AD 62)</span></span></a></li> 
                               <li><a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian <span class="nowrap">Empire <span style="font-size:85%;">(248&nbsp;BC&nbsp;– &nbsp;AD&nbsp;224)</span></span></a></li>
                              </ul> 
                             </div></td>
                           </tr>
                           <tr>
                            <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:9.0em;font-weight:normal;font-size:85%;">AD 224–651</th>
                            <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;padding:0px">
                             <div style="padding:0em 0.25em"> 
                              <ul>
                               <li><a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sasanian <span class="nowrap">Empire <span style="font-size:85%;">(AD 224–651)</span></span></a></li>
                              </ul> 
                             </div></td>
                           </tr>

                         </table>

                       </tr>
                       <tr>
                        <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Medieval and<br>early modern</th>

                            <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:9.0em;font-weight:normal;font-size:85%;">637&nbsp;– 1055</th>

                             <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

                         </div></td>
                       </tr>
                      </tbody>
                     </table>
                     <div></div></td>
                   </tr>
                  </tbody>
                 </table>
                 <div></div></td>
               </tr>
               <tr>
                <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2" style="font-weight:bold;">

                <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Hors d'oeuvre</th>
                <td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
                 <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

                   <li><a href="/wiki/Strained_yogurt" title="Strained yogurt">Labne</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Kashk_e_bademjan" class="mw-redirect" title="Kashk e bademjan">Kashk e bademjan</a></li>

                   <li><a href="/wiki/Mirza_Ghassemi" title="Mirza Ghassemi">Mirza Ghassemi</a></li>

                  </ul> 
                 </div></td>

                   <li><a href="/wiki/Qashqai_language" title="Qashqai language">Qashqai</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Turkmen_language" title="Turkmen language">Turkmen</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Semnani_language" title="Semnani language">Semnani</a></li>
                  </ul> 
                 </div></td>
               </tr>
               <tr>
                <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Minority languages</th>
                <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
                 <div style="padding:0em 0.25em"> 
                  <ul>
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Armenian_language" title="Armenian language">Armenian</a></li>

                   <li><a href="/wiki/Circassian_languages" title="Circassian languages">Circassian</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Georgian_language" title="Georgian language">Georgian</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Domari_language" title="Domari language">Domari</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Jadgali_language" title="Jadgali language">Jadgali</a></li>
                  </ul> 
                 </div></td>
               </tr>

             </table>
            </div>

              </tbody>
             </table>
            </div>

                <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2" style="background:#abdb75;">
                 <div>
                  BR: <a href="/wiki/Biosphere_Reserve" class="mw-redirect" title="Biosphere Reserve">Biosphere Reserve</a> - IW: <a href="/wiki/Ramsar_Convention" title="Ramsar Convention">International Wetland (Ramsar Site)</a> - All names as inscribed by the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Environment,_Iran" class="mw-redirect" title="Department of Environment, Iran">Department of Environment, Iran</a>
                 </div></td>
               </tr>
              </tbody>
             </table>
            </div>

                   <li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Flag_of_Iran.svg/23px-Flag_of_Iran.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="13" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Flag_of_Iran.svg/35px-Flag_of_Iran.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Flag_of_Iran.svg/46px-Flag_of_Iran.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="630" data-file-height="360">&nbsp;</span><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Iran</a></li>

                  </ul>

              </tbody>
             </table>

                  <ul>
                   <li><img alt="Category" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/96/Symbol_category_class.svg/16px-Symbol_category_class.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Category" width="16" height="16" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/96/Symbol_category_class.svg/23px-Symbol_category_class.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/96/Symbol_category_class.svg/31px-Symbol_category_class.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="180" data-file-height="185"> <a href="/wiki/Category:Asia" title="Category:Asia">Category</a></li> 
                   <li><img alt="Portal" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e2/Symbol_portal_class.svg/16px-Symbol_portal_class.svg.png" decoding="async" title="Portal" width="16" height="16" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e2/Symbol_portal_class.svg/23px-Symbol_portal_class.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e2/Symbol_portal_class.svg/31px-Symbol_portal_class.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="180" data-file-height="185"> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Asia" title="Portal:Asia">Asia portal</a></li>
                  </ul> 
                 </div></td>
               </tr>
              </tbody>
             </table>
            </div>

                  <a href="/wiki/OPEC" title="OPEC">Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries</a> (OPEC)
                 </div></th>
               </tr>
               <tr>
                <td colspan="2" class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0px">
                 <div style="padding:0em 0.25em"> 
                  <ul>
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Algeria" title="Economy of Algeria">Algeria</a></li>

                   <li><a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates" title="Economy of the United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a></li>

                  </ul> 
                 </div></td>
               </tr>

       <ul style="margin:0.1em 0 0">
        <li style="display:inline"><span style="display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap"><span style="margin:0 0.5em"><a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Iran.svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of Iran.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Flag_of_Iran.svg/24px-Flag_of_Iran.svg.png" decoding="async" width="24" height="14" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Flag_of_Iran.svg/36px-Flag_of_Iran.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Flag_of_Iran.svg/48px-Flag_of_Iran.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="630" data-file-height="360"></a></span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Iran" title="Portal:Iran">Iran portal</a></span></li>

      <h3> <label for="searchInput">Search</label> </h3> 
      <form action="/w/index.php" id="searchform"> 
       <div id="simpleSearch" data-search-loc="header-navigation">
